title: Family Law
description: Family Law flashcards for bar exam prep

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Marriage and Limitations on Who Can Marry
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 001. Marriage and Limitations on Who Can Marry
cards.front: Marriage and Limitations on Who Can Marry
cards.backPlain: Marriage is the legal union of two individuals; the law imposes various legal obligations and liabilities on the parties. 1. Limitations on who can marry 1.1 Age: Most states impose a minimum age requirement, usually 18, before a person can consent to marriage. Some states allow minors to marry if there is parental consent or judicial approval. 1.2 Consanguinity: People who are too closely related are prohibited from marrying each other. 1.3 Capacity: Each party must have the mental capacity to comprehend and voluntarily consent to the marriage. 1.4 Physical capacity: In many states, marriage is voidable if one party is physically unable to consummate the marriage and the other party was unaware of the physical condition. 1.5 Bigamy/polygamy: No person may marry who has a prior undissolved marriage to another living spouse. 2. Bigamy/polygamy exceptions 2.1 Removal of impediment: Under the Uniform Marriage and Divorce Act, a bigamous marriage can be validated upon removal of the impediment (i.e., when the prior marriage is terminated). 2.2 Presumption of validity: Under the presumption of validity, the last of several marriages is presumed valid, which may be rebutted by evidence that the prior marriages still persist.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main legal limitations on who can marry, and what are the key exceptions related to bigamy or polygamy?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Marriage}} is the legal union of two individuals; the law imposes various legal obligations and liabilities on the parties. 1. Limitations on who can marry 1.1 {{c2::Age}}: Most states impose a minimum age requirement, usually {{c3::18}}, before a person can consent to marriage. Some states allow minors to marry if there is {{c4::parental consent or judicial approval}}. 1.2 {{c5::Consanguinity}}: People who are too closely related are prohibited from marrying each other. 1.3 {{c6::Capacity}}: Each party must have the mental capacity to comprehend and voluntarily consent to the marriage. 1.4 {{c7::Physical capacity}}: In many states, marriage is {{c8::voidable}} if one party is physically unable to consummate the marriage and the other party was unaware of the physical condition. 1.5 {{c9::Bigamy/polygamy}}: No person may marry who has a prior undissolved marriage to another living spouse. 2. Bigamy/polygamy exceptions 2.1 {{c10::Removal of impediment}}: Under the {{c11::Uniform Marriage and Divorce Act}}, a bigamous marriage can be validated upon removal of the impediment (i.e., when the prior marriage is terminated). 2.2 {{c12::Presumption of validity}}: Under the presumption of validity, the {{c13::last of several marriages}} is presumed valid, which may be rebutted by evidence that the prior marriages still persist.
cards.easyContent: Marriage is a legal union that creates obligations between two people, but states limit who can marry based on age, relation, capacity, physical ability to consummate, and existing marriages. Bigamous marriages may be cured if the prior marriage ends or rebut the presumption that the most recent marriage is valid.
cards.mediumContent: Marriage is the legal union of two individuals with legal rights and duties. States restrict who can marry by requiring: (1) minimum age (usually 18, with possible parental or judicial approval for minors); (2) no close consanguinity; (3) mental capacity to understand and voluntarily consent; (4) in many states, physical capacity to consummate, or the marriage may be voidable if the other spouse was unaware; and (5) no prior undissolved marriage (no bigamy/polygamy). Under the Uniform Marriage and Divorce Act, a bigamous marriage may be validated once the prior marriage ends, and generally the last of several marriages is presumed valid unless evidence shows prior marriages still exist.
cards.hardContent: Marriage is the legal union of two individuals that carries statutory rights and obligations. States limit who may marry by requiring: (1) Age—most states require parties to be at least 18 to consent, though minors may marry with parental consent or judicial approval; (2) Consanguinity—marriage between persons too closely related is prohibited; (3) Capacity—each party must understand the nature of the marriage relationship and voluntarily consent; (4) Physical capacity—in many jurisdictions a marriage is voidable if a party is physically unable to consummate and the other spouse did not know of the condition; and (5) No bigamy/polygamy—no marriage is permitted if a prior marriage to a living spouse remains undissolved. Under the Uniform Marriage and Divorce Act, a bigamous marriage can be validated when the prior marriage is terminated, removing the impediment. In addition, under the presumption of validity, the last of several purported marriages is presumed valid unless rebutted by evidence that an earlier marriage still exists.
cards.mnemonic: ACCPB: Age, Consanguinity, Capacity, Physical capacity, no Bigamy.
cards.clozeLite: States limit who can marry by {{c1::age}}, {{c2::no close consanguinity}}, {{c3::mental capacity and consent}}, {{c4::physical capacity to consummate}}, and {{c5::no prior undissolved marriage (no bigamy)}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 002. Requirements to Marry
cards.backPlain: Procedural and state-of-mind requirements exist for a valid marriage. 1. Procedural requirements (most states require both a license and solemnization) 1.1 License: A marriage license must be obtained from the appropriate government-designated licensing officer prior to solemnization. 1.2 Solemnization: The marriage must be solemnized by an authorized clergy member or judicial officer. The license must be completed and signed by the person who solemnized the marriage and filed with the appropriate government office, creating a public record of the marriage. 2. State-of-mind requirements 2.1 Consent: Both parties must consent to marriage, meaning they each intend to take on the obligations of marriage. 2.2 Factors for evaluating consent 2.2.1 Capacity: Parties must have capacity to understand and agree to their actions (e.g., one under the influence of drugs or alcohol may lack capacity to enter into marriage). 2.2.2 Intent: Parties must intend to enter a marriage relationship of their own free will; fraud, duress, coercion, and similar pressures will negate the consent requirement.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the procedural and state-of-mind requirements for a valid marriage?
cards.cloze: Procedural and state-of-mind requirements exist for a valid {{c1::marriage}}. 1. {{c2::Procedural requirements}} (most states require both a {{c3::license}} and {{c4::solemnization}}) 1.1 License: A marriage license must be obtained from the appropriate government-designated licensing officer prior to solemnization. 1.2 Solemnization: The marriage must be solemnized by an authorized {{c5::clergy member}} or {{c6::judicial officer}}. The license must be completed and signed by the person who solemnized the marriage and filed with the appropriate government office, creating a {{c7::public record}} of the marriage. 2. {{c8::State-of-mind requirements}} 2.1 {{c9::Consent}}: Both parties must consent to marriage, meaning they each intend to take on the obligations of marriage. 2.2 Factors for evaluating consent 2.2.1 {{c10::Capacity}}: Parties must have capacity to understand and agree to their actions (e.g., one under the influence of drugs or alcohol may lack capacity to enter into marriage). 2.2.2 {{c11::Intent}}: Parties must intend to enter a marriage relationship of their own free will; {{c12::fraud, duress, or coercion}} will negate the consent requirement.
cards.easyContent: A valid marriage generally requires compliance with procedural rules (a license and proper solemnization) and that both parties knowingly and voluntarily consent to marry. Lack of capacity or intent, such as from fraud or duress, can invalidate consent.
cards.mediumContent: For a valid marriage, most states require: (1) Procedural steps—obtaining a marriage license from the proper official and having the marriage solemnized by an authorized clergy member or judicial officer, with the signed license filed to create a public record; and (2) State-of-mind requirements—both parties must consent, meaning they have capacity to understand the nature of marriage and intend of their own free will to enter the marital relationship, free from fraud, duress, or coercion.
cards.hardContent: A valid marriage requires compliance with both procedural and mental-state requirements. Procedurally, most states require that the parties (1) obtain a marriage license from the appropriate government officer before the ceremony, and (2) have the marriage solemnized by an authorized clergy member or judicial officer, who completes and signs the license and files it with the appropriate office to create a public record. As to state of mind, both parties must consent—each must have sufficient capacity to understand the nature and obligations of marriage and must intend, of their own free will, to enter the marriage. Consent is negated where a party lacks capacity (e.g., due to intoxication) or where the marriage is induced by fraud, duress, coercion, or similar overreaching.
cards.mnemonic: Requirements to marry = "LiS-CI": License, Solemnization, Capacity, Intent.
cards.clozeLite: A valid marriage generally requires {{c1::procedural steps (license and solemnization)}} and {{c2::knowing, voluntary consent with capacity}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 003. Common Law Marriage
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: In a common law marriage, a couple is legally considered married without having registered or performed the usual legal requirements for marriage; common law marriage has been abolished in most states. 2. Requirements (where recognized, a common law marriage is established by) 2.1 Consent: There must be an exchange of consent between two people to be in a permanent, exclusive marital relationship; an agreement to cohabitate alone is insufficient. 2.2 Cohabitation: The couple must cohabitate. 2.3 Holding out publicly as spouses: The parties must hold themselves out publicly as spouses living together, for example by using a joint bank account, sharing the same last name, or telling others they are married. 3. Recognition in other states: Though largely abolished, if a valid common law marriage is formed under one state's laws, it is generally recognized as a valid marriage in other states, even in states where common law marriage is illegal.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a common law marriage, what are its requirements where recognized, and how is it treated by other states?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}}: In a {{c2::common law marriage}}, a couple is legally considered married without having registered or performed the usual legal requirements for marriage; common law marriage has been {{c3::abolished in most states}}. 2. {{c4::Requirements}} (where recognized, a common law marriage is established by) 2.1 {{c5::Consent}}: There must be an exchange of consent between two people to be in a {{c6::permanent, exclusive marital relationship}}; an agreement to {{c7::cohabitate alone is insufficient}}. 2.2 {{c8::Cohabitation}}: The couple must cohabitate. 2.3 {{c9::Holding out publicly as spouses}}: The parties must hold themselves out publicly as spouses living together, for example by using a {{c10::joint bank account}}, sharing the {{c11::same last name}}, or {{c12::telling others they are married}}. 3. {{c13::Recognition in other states}}: Though largely abolished, if a valid common law marriage is formed under one state's laws, it is generally recognized as a valid marriage in other states, even in states where common law marriage is illegal.
cards.easyContent: A common law marriage is a marriage created without a license or ceremony where recognized states treat the couple as married if they consent to a permanent, exclusive marital relationship, cohabit, and hold themselves out as spouses. A valid common law marriage formed in one state is usually recognized in other states.
cards.mediumContent: Common law marriage, now abolished in most states, allows a couple to be legally married without a license or ceremony. Where it is recognized, it generally requires: (1) mutual consent to a permanent, exclusive marital relationship; (2) cohabitation; and (3) holding out publicly as spouses (e.g., joint accounts, shared surname, representing themselves as married). A valid common law marriage formed under the law of one state will usually be recognized as a valid marriage in other states, even those that do not themselves allow common law marriage.
cards.hardContent: In a common law marriage, the parties are legally considered married without meeting the usual formal requirements such as obtaining a license or having a formal ceremony; this doctrine has been abolished in most jurisdictions. In states that still recognize it, a common law marriage is typically established by: (1) mutual consent—an agreement between two people to enter a permanent, exclusive marital relationship, not just to live together; (2) cohabitation; and (3) holding out publicly as spouses, such as by using a joint bank account, adopting the same last name, or affirmatively telling others they are married. Under principles of interstate recognition, a valid common law marriage formed under one state's law is generally recognized as a valid marriage in other states, including those that do not themselves permit new common law marriages.
cards.mnemonic: Common law marriage is C-C-H: Consent, Cohabitation, Holding out.
cards.clozeLite: Common law marriage requires {{c1::no license or ceremony}} plus {{c2::mutual consent to a permanent, exclusive marriage}}, {{c3::cohabitation}}, and {{c4::holding out publicly as spouses}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 004. Premarital Agreements
cards.backPlain: Premarital agreements (prenups) are contracts by which prospective spouses alter the default legal rules governing property and support at divorce or death. Marriage itself is sufficient consideration to support the agreement. Many states follow the Uniform Premarital Agreement Act (UPAA), which governs what may be included in such contracts and imposes validity requirements. To be valid, a premarital agreement generally must be in writing (Statute of Frauds), entered into voluntarily (free from fraud, duress, or overreaching), and based on full and fair financial disclosure (or a knowing waiver after adequate knowledge). These agreements can later be amended or revoked only by a written agreement signed by both parties, and amendments do not need new consideration. Courts strictly scrutinize premarital agreements at enforcement, focusing on voluntariness, disclosure, and unconscionability at execution (and sometimes at enforcement), and may also consider whether each party had independent counsel. By contrast, provisions regarding child custody and child support are not binding on the court and may be void, because custody and support are ultimately decided according to the child’s best interests.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a premarital agreement under the UPAA framework, and what major topics govern its validity, enforcement, and limits?
cards.cloze: Premarital agreements ({{c1::prenups}}) are {{c2::contracts}} by which prospective spouses {{c3::alter default legal rules}} governing property and support at {{c4::divorce or death}}. {{c5::Marriage}} is sufficient {{c6::consideration}}. Under the {{c7::UPAA}}, validity turns on {{c8::writing}}, {{c9::voluntariness}}, and {{c10::full and fair financial disclosure}} (or a knowing waiver). The agreement can be {{c11::amended or revoked only by a later written agreement signed by both parties}}, and {{c12::no new consideration}} is required for an amendment. Courts {{c13::strictly scrutinize}} prenups, focusing on {{c9::voluntariness}}, {{c10::disclosure}}, and {{c14::unconscionability}}. {{c15::Child custody and support}} provisions are {{c16::not binding}} because courts decide those issues based on the {{c17::best interests of the child}}.
cards.easyContent: Premarital agreements (prenups) are contracts that change the default rules for property and support at divorce or death. Marriage is sufficient consideration. Under the UPAA, they must be written, voluntary, and based on full and fair financial disclosure (or a valid waiver). They can be changed or revoked only by another written, signed agreement, without new consideration. Courts strictly scrutinize prenups for voluntariness, disclosure, and unconscionability, and child-related terms are not binding because courts decide custody and support based on the child’s best interests.
cards.mediumContent: A premarital agreement is a contract between prospective spouses altering default rules for property and support at divorce or death, supported by the marriage itself as consideration. Under the UPAA and similar statutes, a prenup must: (1) be in writing (Statute of Frauds); (2) be entered into voluntarily, without fraud, duress, or overreaching; and (3) be based on full and fair financial disclosure (or a knowing waiver after adequate knowledge). It may later be amended or revoked only by a written agreement signed by both parties, and amendments need no new consideration. Courts strictly scrutinize enforcement, focusing on voluntariness, disclosure, and unconscionability at execution (and sometimes at enforcement), and may consider whether each party had independent counsel. Provisions fixing child custody or child support are not binding—and may be void—because courts determine those matters under a best interests of the child standard.
cards.hardContent: Premarital agreements (prenups) are contracts by which prospective spouses modify the default property and support rules applicable at divorce or death; the marriage itself supplies sufficient consideration. Many states follow the UPAA, which governs permissible content and imposes validity requirements. A valid prenup must be in writing to satisfy the Statute of Frauds; must be entered into voluntarily, free from fraud, duress, or overreaching; and must rest on full and fair disclosure of each party’s finances or a knowing waiver after adequate knowledge. A premarital agreement can later be amended or revoked only by a subsequent written agreement signed by both parties, and no separate consideration is required for an amendment. Courts strictly scrutinize premarital contracts at enforcement, examining voluntariness, financial disclosure, and whether the agreement was unconscionable at execution (and, in some jurisdictions, at enforcement). They often consider whether each party had independent legal counsel, which some states require for validity. However, provisions purporting to fix child custody or child support are not binding on the court, and may be void, because custody and support are determined at dissolution under a best interests of the child standard.
cards.mnemonic: Prenup WVD + C: Writing, Voluntary, Disclosure; Child terms don’t bind.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) definition, consideration, and UPAA framework; (2) formal and substantive validity requirements (writing, voluntariness, disclosure); (3) amendment/revocation and enforcement scrutiny; (4) child-related provisions and their limits.
cards.clozeLite: Under the UPAA, a premarital agreement must be {{c1::in writing}}, {{c2::voluntary (no fraud, duress, overreaching)}}, and based on {{c3::full and fair financial disclosure or a knowing waiver}}; {{c4::child custody and support terms are not binding}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 005. Property, Support Rights, and Responsibilities
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Before and during marriage, each spouse owns and controls their own property, but property acquired during marriage may become owned as a tenancy by the entirety. 1.1 Tenancy by the entirety: In many states, where spouses take title to real property jointly, a tenancy by the entirety is presumptively created. If the marriage is dissolved, the parties hold the property as tenants in common. 1.2 Spousal support obligation: Each spouse has an obligation to support the other, and one spouse may be held liable for the other spouse's purchases. Under agency principles, one spouse can be held liable to third parties for purchases made by the other spouse where expressly or impliedly authorized. 1.3 Necessaries doctrine: One spouse may be held liable to creditors for necessaries purchased by the other spouse, such as food, medical care, shelter, and clothing.
cards.frontPrompt: What are spouses’ basic property rights during marriage, and how do spousal support and the necessaries doctrine create liability between spouses and to third parties?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: Before and during marriage, each spouse {{c1::owns and controls their own property}}, but property acquired during marriage may become owned as a {{c2::tenancy by the entirety}}. 1.1 {{c3::Tenancy by the entirety}}: In many states, where spouses take title to real property jointly, a tenancy by the entirety is {{c4::presumptively created}}. If the marriage is dissolved, the parties hold the property as {{c5::tenants in common}}. 1.2 {{c6::Spousal support obligation}}: Each spouse has an obligation to {{c7::support the other}}, and one spouse may be held liable for the other spouse's purchases. Under {{c8::agency principles}}, one spouse can be held liable to third parties for purchases made by the other spouse where {{c9::expressly or impliedly authorized}}. 1.3 {{c10::Necessaries doctrine}}: One spouse may be held liable to creditors for {{c11::necessaries}} purchased by the other spouse, such as food, medical care, shelter, and clothing.
cards.easyContent: Each spouse generally owns and controls their own property during marriage, but jointly acquired real property may be held as a tenancy by the entirety. Spouses have a duty to support each other and may be liable for each other’s purchases of necessaries.
cards.mediumContent: Each spouse retains ownership and control over their separate property, but in many states, jointly titled real property acquired during marriage is presumed to be held as a tenancy by the entirety, converting to a tenancy in common upon divorce. Spouses owe each other a duty of support, and under agency principles and the necessaries doctrine, one spouse can be liable to third parties for the other spouse’s authorized purchases and for necessaries such as food, shelter, clothing, and medical care.
cards.hardContent: Before and during marriage, each spouse owns and controls their own separate property. However, property acquired during marriage and taken in both spouses’ names is, in many states, presumptively held as a tenancy by the entirety; upon dissolution of the marriage, this is converted into a tenancy in common. Each spouse has a legal obligation to support the other and may be held liable for the other spouse’s purchases. Under agency principles, one spouse can be liable to third parties for purchases made by the other where the purchasing spouse had express or implied authority. Separately, under the necessaries doctrine, a spouse may be held liable to creditors for necessaries—such as food, medical care, shelter, and clothing—purchased by the other spouse.
cards.mnemonic: T.E.N.: Tenancy by entirety, Economic support duty, Necessaries liability.
cards.clozeLite: Each spouse keeps {{c1::ownership and control of separate property}}, but jointly titled marital realty is {{c2::presumed a tenancy by the entirety}}. Spouses owe a {{c3::duty of support}} and, under the {{c4::necessaries doctrine}}, one spouse can be {{c5::liable to third parties for the other’s necessaries}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 006. Annulment
cards.backPlain: Annulment is a judicial declaration that an alleged marriage was invalid from its inception because an impediment existed at the time of marriage. Legally, the marriage is treated as if it never occurred. A marriage can be annulled if it is void or voidable (the precise classification varies by state). Common grounds for annulment include bigamy or polygamy, consanguinity (close blood relationship), non-age, incurable physical impotence, and incapacity to consent (e.g., mental incompetence, intoxication, fraud, or duress). On annulment, many states allow temporary spousal support during the suit, though fewer allow ongoing support afterward. Most courts divide property with the aim of placing the parties as nearly as possible in the positions they occupied before the marriage commenced.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an annulment, in broad terms, and what main issues do courts consider (grounds, support, and property) when granting one?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Annulment}} is a judicial declaration that an alleged marriage was {{c2::invalid from its inception}} due to an {{c3::impediment at the time of marriage}}, so the marriage is treated as if it {{c4::never occurred}}. A marriage may be annulled if it is {{c5::void}} or {{c6::voidable}} (the exact classification varies by state). Common grounds include {{c7::bigamy or polygamy}}, {{c8::consanguinity}}, {{c9::non-age}}, {{c10::incurable physical impotence}}, and {{c11::incapacity to consent}}. Many states allow {{c12::temporary spousal support}} during the annulment action, and most courts divide property to approximate each party’s {{c13::pre-marriage position}}.
cards.easyContent: Annulment is a court decree that a supposed marriage was invalid from the start because an impediment existed when the parties married. Typical issues are: the grounds that made the marriage void or voidable, whether any support is allowed, and how property is divided to restore the parties to their pre-marriage positions.
cards.mediumContent: Annulment is a judicial declaration that a marriage was void or voidable because an impediment existed at the time of marriage, so in law the marriage never occurred. Core issues are: (1) identifying qualifying grounds (e.g., bigamy, consanguinity, non-age, impotence, or incapacity to consent); and (2) determining the consequences—temporary versus ongoing spousal support and a property division that generally aims to restore each party to their pre-marriage status.
cards.hardContent: Annulment is a judicial declaration that an alleged marriage was invalid from its inception because some legal impediment existed at the time of marriage, so the marriage is treated as though it never occurred. A marriage may be annulled if it is void or voidable, though which specific grounds create a void versus a voidable marriage varies by state. The doctrine focuses on three clusters of issues: (1) the legal nature and effect of annulment—that the marriage is considered never to have existed; (2) the recognized grounds, such as bigamy or polygamy, consanguinity, non-age, incurable physical impotence, and incapacity to consent due to mental incompetence, intoxication, fraud, or duress; and (3) the consequences if an annulment is granted, including whether temporary or post-annulment support is available and how property should be divided, with most courts attempting to return the parties as closely as possible to their pre-marriage positions.
cards.mnemonic: Annulment = BAD INK: Bigamy, Age, Duress, Incapacity, Non-consent, Kinship.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) definition and effect of annulment; (2) specific grounds; (3) consequences for support and property division.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::annulment}} declares a marriage {{c2::void or voidable}} due to an {{c3::impediment at the time of marriage}}, and courts then decide {{c4::support}} and {{c5::property division to restore pre-marriage status}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 007. Divorce
cards.front: Divorce – Overview, No-Fault, Defenses, and Legal Separation
cards.backPlain: Divorce is the judicial termination of the marriage relationship. Historically, divorce was primarily fault-based, but today every state offers some form of no-fault divorce, typically on grounds like irretrievable breakdown, living separate and apart for a specified period, or incompatibility. Some defenses to divorce may exist, but courts generally will not compel a marriage to continue if one spouse seeks dissolution. In contrast, legal separation is a judicially recognized parting that does not terminate the marriage or permit remarriage, but allows the court to adjudicate issues such as property, support, and custody, and in some states may later be converted into an absolute divorce.
cards.frontPrompt: How does modern no-fault divorce fit within the broader divorce framework, what is the role of defenses, and how does legal separation differ from divorce?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::divorce decree}} {{c2::terminates the marriage relationship}}. Historically, divorce was {{c3::fault-based}}, but now every state offers some form of {{c4::no-fault divorce}}, typically on grounds such as {{c5::irretrievable breakdown}}, {{c6::living separate and apart for a specified period}}, or {{c7::incompatibility}}. Some {{c8::defenses to divorce}} exist, but courts generally will not {{c9::force a marriage to continue}} if one spouse seeks dissolution. In contrast, {{c10::legal separation}} is a judicially recognized parting that {{c11::does not terminate the marriage}} or permit {{c12::remarriage}}, but allows adjudication of {{c13::property, support, and custody}} and in some states may later be {{c14::converted into an absolute divorce}}.
cards.easyContent: Divorce is the court-ordered end of a marriage, usually under modern no-fault rules such as irretrievable breakdown, separation for a set time, or incompatibility. Defenses exist but generally cannot force a marriage to continue. Legal separation, by contrast, adjusts rights and obligations but does not end the marriage or permit remarriage, and may convert to divorce in some states.
cards.mediumContent: A divorce decree terminates the marriage relationship. While some states retain fault-based grounds, all states now offer no-fault divorce, commonly based on irretrievable breakdown, living separate and apart for a set time, or incompatibility. Some defenses may be available, but courts generally will not require an unwilling spouse to remain married. Legal separation is a judicially recognized separation that does not terminate the marriage or permit remarriage, but addresses issues like property division, spousal support, custody, and child support, and in some jurisdictions can be converted into an absolute divorce after a prescribed period at the parties’ request.
cards.hardContent: Divorce is the judicial dissolution of the marital relationship. Traditionally, divorce required proof of fault, but every state now offers some form of no-fault divorce, even if some still recognize fault grounds. Typical no-fault grounds include: (1) an irretrievably broken marriage or irreconcilable differences, often the primary or exclusive ground; (2) living separate and apart for a prescribed period, commonly six months to one year; and (3) incompatibility. Some states recognize defenses to divorce—such as collusion, condonation, or recrimination—but courts generally will not compel the continuation of a marriage when one spouse seeks dissolution. In contrast, legal separation is a judicially recognized parting that does not terminate the marriage and does not permit remarriage. In a separation proceeding, the court may adjudicate property rights, spousal support, child custody, and child support, and in some states, a legal separation may later be converted into an absolute divorce after a specified period upon request of the parties.
cards.mnemonic: I-S-I: Irretrievable, Separation, Incompatibility for no-fault.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) no-fault vs. fault and grounds for divorce; (2) defenses to divorce; (3) legal separation versus divorce and conversion rules.
cards.clozeLite: Modern divorce: all states allow {{c1::no-fault divorce}} (e.g., {{c2::irretrievable breakdown or separation}}). {{c3::Defenses rarely block dissolution}}. {{c4::Legal separation}} {{c5::does not end marriage or allow remarriage}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 008. Jurisdiction over Annulment and Divorce
cards.front: Jurisdiction over Annulment and Divorce – Overview
cards.backPlain: Jurisdiction over marriage-related actions is vested in state courts. 1. Annulment: Jurisdiction is typically proper in any state in which either spouse is domiciled, and in most states also in the state where the marriage was entered into and recognized. 2. Divorce: Subject-matter jurisdiction is generally based on domicile of one or both spouses in the forum, sometimes coupled with a durational residency requirement to limit forum shopping. Sister states must recognize a valid divorce decree under the Full Faith and Credit Clause if the rendering state had proper domicile-based jurisdiction. 3. Status vs. property/support: While a court can adjudicate marital status based on domicile alone, it may not determine rights in out-of-state property or enter binding support orders unless it has personal jurisdiction over both spouses.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the overall framework for jurisdiction in annulment and divorce actions, including domicile-based status jurisdiction, durational residency, and limits on property and support orders?
cards.cloze: Jurisdiction over {{c1::marriage-related actions}} is vested in {{c2::state courts}}. 1. {{c3::Annulment}}: Jurisdiction is typically proper in any state in which either spouse is {{c4::domiciled}}, and in most states also in the state where the {{c5::marriage was entered into and recognized}}. 2. {{c6::Divorce}}: Subject-matter jurisdiction is generally based on {{c7::domicile}} of one or both spouses in the forum, sometimes coupled with a {{c8::durational residency}} requirement to limit {{c9::forum shopping}}. Sister states must recognize a valid divorce decree under the {{c10::Full Faith and Credit Clause}} if the rendering state had proper {{c11::domicile-based jurisdiction}}. 3. {{c12::Status vs. property/support}}: A court can adjudicate {{c13::marital status}} based on domicile alone, but it may not determine rights in {{c14::out-of-state property}} or enter binding {{c15::support orders}} unless it has {{c16::personal jurisdiction over both spouses}}.
cards.easyContent: State courts handle marriage-related actions. Annulment and divorce are generally based on domicile (plus possible durational residency for divorce), and valid divorce decrees get Full Faith and Credit. But to decide property or support, the court needs personal jurisdiction over both spouses.
cards.mediumContent: State courts have jurisdiction over annulment and divorce. Annulment jurisdiction is usually proper where either spouse is domiciled or where the marriage was entered and recognized. Divorce jurisdiction requires that at least one spouse be domiciled in the forum, and many states impose a durational residency requirement to curb forum shopping. Other states must recognize a divorce decree under Full Faith and Credit if the rendering state had domicile-based jurisdiction. However, adjudicating status differs from adjudicating economic incidents: courts generally cannot decide rights in out-of-state property or issue binding support orders without personal jurisdiction over both spouses.
cards.hardContent: Jurisdiction over marriage actions lies in state courts. For annulment, a state where either spouse is domiciled has jurisdiction, and most states also allow jurisdiction in the state where the marriage was entered into and recognized. Divorce jurisdiction is based on domicile of one or both spouses in the forum, often with an added durational residency requirement to reduce forum shopping. Under the Full Faith and Credit Clause, a divorce decree issued by a state that had proper domicile-based jurisdiction must be recognized by sister states. Importantly, there is a distinction between status and economic incidents: while a state may adjudicate marital status based solely on domicile, it typically cannot determine rights to out-of-state property or enter binding spousal or child support decrees unless it has personal jurisdiction over both spouses.
cards.mnemonic: D-D-F-PJ: Divorce needs Domicile, Durational residency, Full faith, plus Personal Jurisdiction for money.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) jurisdiction for annulment; (2) jurisdiction and durational residency for divorce plus Full Faith and Credit; (3) limits on jurisdiction over out-of-state property and support without personal jurisdiction.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Divorce jurisdiction}} is based on a spouse’s {{c2::domicile}} (often with {{c3::durational residency}}), and other states must {{c4::give Full Faith and Credit}} if domicile was proper. But {{c5::property and support orders}} require {{c6::personal jurisdiction over both spouses}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 009. Division of Property Overview
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: When property is divided upon marriage dissolution, there are two main approaches used, depending on the state. 1.1 Equitable division of marital property: Each spouse takes their separate property and the court divides property acquired during the marriage on an equitable basis. This is the most popular approach—assume this approach for MEE purposes unless provided otherwise. 1.2 Community property: Property acquired during the marriage is owned 50/50 by each spouse, unless acquired by gift or bequest, in which case it is considered separate property. 1.3 Approach to property division (courts will do the following): 1.3.1 Categorize property: Classify property as marital or separate. 1.3.2 Determine equitable distribution of marital property: Distribute marital property between spouses based on relevant factors. Note: If asked to divide marital property, discuss the approach and how it works, then explain how the relevant factors will influence how the court would divide the property. 1.4 Modification: Property distribution decrees are generally not modifiable in most states.
cards.frontPrompt: On dissolution of marriage, what are the two main state approaches to dividing property, and how do courts categorize and distribute marital versus separate property?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: When property is divided upon marriage dissolution, there are two main approaches used, depending on the state. 1.1 {{c1::Equitable division of marital property}}: Each spouse takes their {{c2::separate property}} and the court divides property acquired during the marriage on an {{c3::equitable basis}}. This is the {{c4::most popular approach}}—assume this approach for MEE purposes unless provided otherwise. 1.2 {{c5::Community property}}: Property acquired during the marriage is owned {{c6::50/50 by each spouse}}, unless acquired by {{c7::gift or bequest}}, in which case it is considered {{c8::separate property}}. 1.3 Approach to property division (courts will do the following): 1.3.1 {{c9::Categorize property}}: Classify property as {{c10::marital or separate}}. 1.3.2 {{c11::Determine equitable distribution of marital property}}: Distribute marital property between spouses based on {{c12::relevant factors}}. Note: If asked to divide marital property, discuss the {{c13::approach}} and how it works, then explain how the relevant factors will influence how the court would divide the property. 1.4 {{c14::Modification}}: Property distribution decrees are generally {{c15::not modifiable}} in most states.
cards.easyContent: States divide property at divorce either under equitable distribution or community property systems. In equitable distribution states, each spouse keeps separate property and marital property is divided fairly; in community property states, marital property is owned 50/50.
cards.mediumContent: On divorce, most states follow equitable distribution: each spouse keeps their separate property and the court equitably divides property acquired during the marriage, considering relevant factors. A minority follow community property, where property acquired during marriage is owned 50/50 by the spouses, with gifts and bequests typically treated as separate property. Courts first categorize property as marital or separate, then distribute marital property accordingly, and property division decrees are generally final and not modifiable.
cards.hardContent: At dissolution, states use two main property division regimes. Under the majority equitable distribution approach, each spouse takes his or her separate property, and the court divides property acquired during the marriage on an equitable—not necessarily equal—basis; assume this approach on the MEE unless told otherwise. Under the community property approach, property acquired during the marriage is presumptively owned 50/50 by each spouse, while assets acquired by gift or bequest are ordinarily classified as separate. Courts generally proceed by first categorizing assets as marital versus separate, then determining an equitable distribution of the marital property in light of relevant factors (such as the length of the marriage, contributions of the parties, and economic circumstances). Property distribution decrees are usually final and not subject to later modification in most states.
cards.mnemonic: "E/C": Equitable=fair; Community=equal 50/50.
cards.clozeLite: Most states use {{c1::equitable distribution}}; a minority use {{c2::community property}}. Courts first {{c3::classify marital vs. separate}} then {{c4::divide marital property}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 010. Categorizing Property
cards.backPlain: In categorizing property, courts must distinguish between separate and marital property. 1. Separate property (generally includes): 1.1 Before marriage: property acquired before marriage by either spouse. 1.2 By gift or bequest: property acquired by gift, bequest, devise, or descent (i.e., family money) during marriage by either spouse. 1.3 Separate property proceeds: property acquired with separate property proceeds by either spouse. 1.4 Appreciation because of time: appreciation of separate property due to the passage of time (as opposed to the efforts of either spouse). 2. Marital property (generally): 2.1 Definition: all property acquired during marriage that is not separate property, regardless of who holds title. 2.2 Appreciation because of effort: appreciation of separate property due to the efforts of either spouse is usually marital property. 2.3 Pensions: the portion of a pension earned by one spouse during marriage is considered marital property. 2.4 Professional license or degree: in some states, reimbursement may be ordered if one spouse provided support that contributed to the other spouse's degree or license. 3. Commingled property: separate property that is inextricably mingled with marital property, or with separate property of the other spouse, can become marital property.
cards.frontPrompt: How do courts categorize property as separate versus marital in family law, and what kinds of assets fall into each category?
cards.cloze: In categorizing property, courts must distinguish between {{c1::separate}} and {{c2::marital}} property. 1. {{c1::Separate property}} (generally includes): 1.1 Before marriage: property acquired before marriage by either spouse. 1.2 By gift or bequest: property acquired by {{c3::gift, bequest, devise, or descent}} (i.e., family money) during marriage by either spouse. 1.3 {{c4::Separate property proceeds}}: property acquired with separate property proceeds by either spouse. 1.4 Appreciation because of time: appreciation of separate property due to the {{c5::passage of time}} (as opposed to the efforts of either spouse). 2. {{c2::Marital property}} (generally): 2.1 Definition: {{c6::all property acquired during marriage that is not separate property, regardless of who holds title}}. 2.2 Appreciation because of effort: appreciation of separate property due to the {{c7::efforts of either spouse}} is usually marital property. 2.3 {{c8::Pensions}}: the portion of a pension earned by one spouse during marriage is considered marital property. 2.4 {{c9::Professional license or degree}}: in some states, reimbursement may be ordered if one spouse provided support that contributed to the other spouse's degree or license. 3. {{c10::Commingled property}}: separate property that is inextricably mingled with marital property, or with separate property of the other spouse, can become marital property.
cards.easyContent: Courts classify assets as either separate or marital property. Separate property is typically what a spouse owned before marriage or received as a gift or inheritance, while marital property is generally anything acquired during the marriage that is not separate and can include increased value due to either spouse’s efforts.
cards.mediumContent: Courts first categorize assets as separate or marital. Separate property includes assets owned before marriage, gifts or inheritances to one spouse during marriage, assets bought with separate-property proceeds, and passive appreciation of separate property. Marital property is all other property acquired during marriage, including active appreciation due to either spouse’s efforts, the portion of pensions earned during marriage, and in some states, reimbursement for support that helped a spouse obtain a degree or license. Commingling can convert separate property into marital property.
cards.hardContent: In equitable distribution, courts must distinguish between separate and marital property. Separate property generally includes: (1) property acquired before marriage by either spouse; (2) property acquired during marriage by gift, bequest, devise, or descent to one spouse; (3) property acquired with separate-property proceeds; and (4) appreciation of separate property attributable solely to the passage of time or other passive factors, not to either spouse’s efforts. Marital property is all property acquired during marriage that is not separate property, regardless of who holds title. It usually includes: (1) appreciation of separate property that is attributable to the efforts of either spouse; (2) the portion of pensions or similar benefits earned during the marriage; and (3) in some states, a reimbursement claim where one spouse’s support helped the other obtain a professional degree or license. Separate property that is inextricably commingled with marital property, or with the other spouse’s separate property, can be treated as marital property.
cards.mnemonic: SPAM-C: Separate, Pensions, Appreciation, Marital, Commingled.
cards.clozeLite: Courts first categorize assets as {{c1::separate or marital}}. {{c2::Separate property}} includes premarital assets, {{c3::gifts or inheritances to one spouse}}, and {{c4::passive appreciation}}; {{c5::marital property}} is all other property acquired during marriage.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 011. Distribution of Property
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Once a court categorizes property as separate or marital, it equitably distributes marital property between both spouses. Courts have significant discretion in determining equitable distribution. 2. Factors: Courts look at all relevant factors concerning how marital property was accumulated and each party's needs going forward, including: 2.1 Income, educational or vocational skills, and employability of each party. 2.2 Duration of the marriage. 2.3 Standard of living during the marriage. 2.4 Assets, debts, and liabilities of the parties. 2.5 Obligations for support arising out of a prior marriage. 2.6 Contributions made by each spouse toward accumulation of marital property, including contributions to the home and household. 2.7 Needs of the parties. 2.8 Provisions for custody of minor children. 2.9 Whether distribution is in lieu of alimony or spousal support. 2.10 Health of the parties. 3. Fault as a factor: Marital fault of either spouse (e.g., infidelity) is not a relevant factor in most jurisdictions. Note: If a question asks you to divide property, be sure to utilize the facts of the question in discussing relevant factors.
cards.frontPrompt: After property is classified as marital or separate, how do courts equitably distribute marital property, and what factors do they consider (including whether fault matters)?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: Once a court categorizes property as separate or marital, it {{c1::equitably distributes}} marital property between both spouses. Courts have significant {{c2::discretion}} in determining equitable distribution. 2. Factors: Courts look at all relevant factors concerning how marital property was accumulated and each party's needs going forward, including: 2.1 {{c3::Income, educational or vocational skills, and employability}} of each party. 2.2 {{c4::Duration of the marriage}}. 2.3 {{c5::Standard of living}} during the marriage. 2.4 {{c6::Assets, debts, and liabilities}} of the parties. 2.5 {{c7::Obligations for support arising out of a prior marriage}}. 2.6 {{c8::Contributions}} made by each spouse toward accumulation of marital property, including contributions to the home and household. 2.7 {{c9::Needs of the parties}}. 2.8 {{c10::Provisions for custody of minor children}}. 2.9 Whether distribution is {{c11::in lieu of alimony or spousal support}}. 2.10 {{c12::Health of the parties}}. 3. Fault as a factor: {{c13::Marital fault of either spouse (e.g., infidelity) is not a relevant factor in most jurisdictions}}. Note: If a question asks you to divide property, be sure to utilize the facts of the question in discussing relevant factors.
cards.easyContent: Once property is classified, courts equitably distribute marital property using a multi-factor test and broad discretion. Most jurisdictions do not consider marital fault like infidelity in making the distribution.
cards.mediumContent: After classifying assets as separate or marital, courts equitably distribute marital property between the spouses, with substantial discretion. Relevant factors include income, education and employability, length of the marriage, standard of living, the parties’ assets and debts, prior support obligations, contributions to acquiring marital property (including homemaking), each party’s needs, custody arrangements for minor children, whether the award substitutes for alimony, and the parties’ health. Marital fault is generally not a relevant factor.
cards.hardContent: Equitable distribution begins after property is classified as separate or marital. Courts then equitably distribute only the marital property, exercising broad discretion. In determining what is equitable, courts consider all relevant circumstances, commonly including: (1) each party’s income, educational or vocational skills, and employability; (2) the duration of the marriage; (3) the standard of living during the marriage; (4) the parties’ assets, debts, and liabilities; (5) obligations for support arising from a prior marriage; (6) contributions by each spouse toward accumulation of marital property, including nonmonetary contributions to the home and household; (7) the current and future needs of the parties; (8) provisions for custody of minor children; (9) whether the allocation of property is in lieu of alimony or spousal support; and (10) the physical and mental health of the parties. In most jurisdictions, marital fault (such as infidelity) is not a relevant factor in property distribution, even though it may be emotionally salient in fact patterns.
cards.mnemonic: Equity FACTS: Fault Away, Consider Total Situation.
cards.clozeLite: Courts {{c1::equitably distribute only marital property}} using a {{c2::multi-factor test}} and {{c3::broad discretion}}; {{c4::marital fault is generally not considered}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 012. Spousal Support
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Spousal support (also called alimony or maintenance) can be awarded if a spouse's separate property and earning capacity are insufficient for that spouse's reasonable maintenance. 1.1 Discretion: Courts have significant discretion in determining whether and to what extent to award spousal support. Needs are determined under the totality of the circumstances. 1.2 Purpose: Spousal support ensures sufficient income for a spouse who became economically dependent, in whole or in part, due to the marriage relationship. 1.3 Terms: Spousal support can be awarded short-term or indefinitely, and as a lump sum or periodic payments. 2. Types of spousal support: Common types include Permanent Periodic Spousal Support, Rehabilitative Spousal Support, Lump Sum Spousal Support, and Reimbursement Spousal Support. 3. Factors: Relevant factors in determining spousal support include: 3.1 Financial resources of each party. 3.2 Standard of living established during the marriage. 3.3 Time necessary for the party seeking support to obtain employment, including education and training. 3.4 Contribution of each party to the marriage, including childcare, career support of the other spouse, and contributions to the home. 3.5 Ability of the spouse paying support to meet their own needs. 4. Marital fault: Marital fault (e.g., infidelity) is not a relevant factor in most states.
cards.frontPrompt: When may a court award spousal support (alimony), what types exist, and what factors guide the amount and duration (including whether fault matters)?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Spousal support}} (also called {{c2::alimony}} or {{c3::maintenance}}) can be awarded if a spouse's separate property and earning capacity are insufficient for that spouse's reasonable maintenance. 1.1 {{c4::Discretion}}: Courts have significant discretion in determining whether and to what extent to award spousal support. Needs are determined under the {{c5::totality of the circumstances}}. 1.2 {{c6::Purpose}}: Spousal support ensures sufficient income for a spouse who became economically dependent, in whole or in part, due to the marriage relationship. 1.3 {{c7::Terms}}: Spousal support can be awarded short-term or indefinitely, and as a lump sum or periodic payments. 2. Types of spousal support: Common types include {{c8::Permanent Periodic Spousal Support}}, {{c9::Rehabilitative Spousal Support}}, {{c10::Lump Sum Spousal Support}}, and {{c11::Reimbursement Spousal Support}}. 3. Factors: Relevant factors in determining spousal support include: 3.1 {{c12::Financial resources}} of each party. 3.2 {{c13::Standard of living}} established during the marriage. 3.3 {{c14::Time necessary for the party seeking support to obtain employment}}, including education and training. 3.4 {{c15::Contribution of each party to the marriage}}, including childcare, career support of the other spouse, and contributions to the home. 3.5 {{c16::Ability of the spouse paying support to meet their own needs}}. 4. Marital fault: {{c17::Marital fault (e.g., infidelity) is not a relevant factor in most states}}.
cards.easyContent: Spousal support (alimony) is a discretionary award to help a spouse who cannot meet reasonable needs with their own property and income. Courts consider needs, resources, and contributions of each spouse, and in most states marital fault does not control the award.
cards.mediumContent: Courts may award spousal support when a spouse’s separate property and earning capacity are insufficient for reasonable maintenance. Courts have broad discretion and look at the totality of the circumstances. Support can be short-term or permanent, paid periodically or in a lump sum, and may be permanent periodic, rehabilitative, lump-sum, or reimbursement support. Key factors include each party’s financial resources, the marital standard of living, time needed for the supported spouse to become self-supporting, each party’s contributions to the marriage (including homemaking and childcare), and the paying spouse’s ability to meet their own needs. Marital fault is generally not a relevant factor.
cards.hardContent: Spousal support (alimony or maintenance) is a discretionary remedy designed to provide sufficient income for a spouse who has become economically dependent as a result of the marriage. It may be awarded when the spouse’s separate property and earning capacity do not cover reasonable maintenance. Courts have broad discretion and assess need and amount under the totality of the circumstances. Spousal support can be structured as short-term or indefinite, and as periodic payments or a lump sum. Common types include: (1) permanent periodic support for long-term needs; (2) rehabilitative support to allow the recipient to gain education or training to become self-sufficient; (3) lump-sum support, often nonmodifiable; and (4) reimbursement support to compensate a spouse who supported the other’s education or career. Relevant factors include each party’s financial resources; the standard of living established during the marriage; the time needed for the supported spouse to obtain education or training and secure employment; each spouse’s contributions to the marriage, including childcare and career support; and the payor’s ability to meet their own needs while paying support. In most jurisdictions, marital fault such as infidelity is not a basis to increase or deny spousal support.
cards.mnemonic: Spousal support: PRLR types; factors = Finances, Lifestyle, Time, Contributions, Ability (FLTCA).
cards.clozeLite: Courts may award {{c1::spousal support}} when a spouse’s {{c2::separate property and earning capacity}} are insufficient for {{c3::reasonable maintenance}}, considering {{c4::financial resources, marital lifestyle, time to self-support, contributions, and ability to pay}}; {{c5::marital fault is generally not relevant}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 013. Child Support
cards.backPlain: Both parents have an absolute duty to support their children. 1. Guidelines and formulas: 1.1 Each state has guidelines to determine the proper amount of child support owed. 1.2 Guidelines are usually based on a formula that considers the number of children, their ages, healthcare needs, any special needs, and parents' incomes. 1.3 Time share (how much time the children live with each parent) is also a factor. 2. Duration: Child support obligations generally last until the child reaches the age of majority or is otherwise emancipated. 3. Independent from visitation rights: Custodial parents cannot deny visitation rights based on a parent's failure to make child support payments. 4. Jurisdiction: 4.1 Full faith and credit is given to child support orders issued in other states as long as the issuing court had proper jurisdiction and the parties had reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard. 4.2 The issuing court has continuing exclusive jurisdiction to modify the order if the child or one of the parties resides in-state, unless the parties have moved out of state but consent to the issuing court's ongoing jurisdiction.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the basic rules governing child support obligations, including guideline calculations, duration, relation to visitation, and jurisdiction to enforce and modify orders?
cards.cloze: Both parents have an {{c1::absolute duty to support their children}}. 1. Guidelines and formulas: 1.1 Each state has {{c2::guidelines}} to determine the proper amount of child support owed. 1.2 Guidelines are usually based on a {{c3::formula}} that considers the {{c4::number of children}}, their {{c5::ages}}, {{c6::healthcare needs}}, any {{c7::special needs}}, and parents' {{c8::incomes}}. 1.3 {{c9::Time share}} (how much time the children live with each parent) is also a factor. 2. Duration: Child support obligations generally last until the child {{c10::reaches the age of majority}} or is otherwise {{c11::emancipated}}. 3. Independent from visitation rights: {{c12::Custodial parents cannot deny visitation rights based on a parent's failure to make child support payments}}. 4. Jurisdiction: 4.1 {{c13::Full faith and credit}} is given to child support orders issued in other states as long as the issuing court had proper jurisdiction and the parties had reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard. 4.2 The issuing court has {{c14::continuing exclusive jurisdiction}} to modify the order if the child or one of the parties resides in-state, unless the parties have moved out of state but {{c15::consent to the issuing court's ongoing jurisdiction}}.
cards.easyContent: Both parents have a strict duty to support their children, and states use guidelines and formulas to set the amount. Support usually lasts until majority or emancipation, is independent of visitation rights, and child support orders receive full faith and credit with continuing exclusive jurisdiction to modify in the issuing court.
cards.mediumContent: Child support is an absolute obligation of both parents. States apply guideline formulas that typically account for the number and ages of children, their health and special needs, parents’ incomes, and each parent’s timeshare. Support generally continues until the child reaches the age of majority or is emancipated. A parent’s failure to pay support does not justify denying visitation. Under federal and uniform acts, valid child support orders from one state receive full faith and credit in other states if the issuing court had jurisdiction and provided notice and opportunity to be heard, and the issuing court retains continuing exclusive jurisdiction to modify as long as the child or a party remains or the parties consent.
cards.hardContent: Both parents owe an absolute duty to support their children. States set the amount primarily by guidelines, which use formulas based on factors such as the number of children, their ages, healthcare and special needs, parents’ incomes, and the amount of time the children reside with each parent (timeshare). Child support typically continues until the child reaches the age of majority or is emancipated by events such as marriage, military service, or self-support under state law. Child support is legally distinct from custody and visitation: a custodial parent may not deny visitation because the other parent is behind on payments. For jurisdiction, a valid child support order issued by a state court receives full faith and credit if the court had proper jurisdiction and provided reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard. Under continuing exclusive jurisdiction rules, the issuing court retains authority to modify its order as long as the child or one parent remains in the state, unless all parties move away but affirmatively consent to the original court’s ongoing jurisdiction.
cards.mnemonic: G-DIVJ: Guidelines, Duration, Independent of visitation, Jurisdiction.
cards.clozeLite: Child support is an {{c1::absolute obligation of both parents}}, set by {{c2::state guideline formulas}}, {{c3::continues until majority or emancipation}}, is {{c4::independent of visitation rights}}, and orders have {{c5::full faith and credit with continuing exclusive jurisdiction to modify}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 014. Child Custody and Visitation Rights
cards.backPlain: 1. Types of custody: 1.1 Legal custody: the right to make major decisions affecting the child's life. 1.2 Physical custody: possession and control of the child. 1.3 Joint custody: can be either or both of the following: 1.3.1 Parents share decision-making, but the child lives with one parent. 1.3.2 The child divides time between each parent's home. 2. Custody factors: In determining custody, courts focus on the child's best interests, looking at multiple factors, including: 2.1 Parents' wishes. 2.2 Child's wishes, given more weight if the child is older, and significantly less weight for young children (e.g., under age eight). 2.3 Ability and willingness of each parent to provide for the child's needs. 2.4 Interaction and interrelationship of the child with parents, siblings, and others who affect the child's best interests. 2.5 Child's adjustment to home, school, and community. 3. Visitation: 3.1 When one parent is granted sole physical custody, the other parent is generally entitled to reasonable visitation. 3.2 Exception: Visitation rights may be denied if the court determines visitation would endanger the child's wellbeing. 3.3 Non-parents: Non-parents may be given visitation rights if: 3.3.1 The non-parent has a substantial relationship with the child. 3.3.2 Non-parent visitation is in the child's best interests. 3.3.3 The fact finder gives special consideration to the wishes of fit parents regarding visitation rights.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main types of child custody, what factors govern the best-interests custody determination, and when can parents or non-parents obtain or be denied visitation?
cards.cloze: 1. Types of custody: 1.1 {{c1::Legal custody}}: the right to make major decisions affecting the child's life. 1.2 {{c2::Physical custody}}: possession and control of the child. 1.3 {{c3::Joint custody}}: can be either or both of the following: 1.3.1 Parents share decision-making, but the child lives with one parent. 1.3.2 The child divides time between each parent's home. 2. Custody factors: In determining custody, courts focus on the child's {{c4::best interests}}, looking at multiple factors, including: 2.1 {{c5::Parents' wishes}}. 2.2 {{c6::Child's wishes}}, given more weight if the child is older, and significantly less weight for young children (e.g., under age eight). 2.3 {{c7::Ability and willingness of each parent to provide for the child's needs}}. 2.4 {{c8::Interaction and interrelationship}} of the child with parents, siblings, and others who affect the child's best interests. 2.5 Child's {{c9::adjustment to home, school, and community}}. 3. Visitation: 3.1 When one parent is granted sole physical custody, the other parent is generally entitled to {{c10::reasonable visitation}}. 3.2 Exception: Visitation rights may be denied if the court determines visitation would {{c11::endanger the child's wellbeing}}. 3.3 Non-parents: Non-parents may be given visitation rights if: 3.3.1 The non-parent has a {{c12::substantial relationship}} with the child. 3.3.2 Non-parent visitation is in the child's {{c13::best interests}}. 3.3.3 The fact finder gives {{c14::special consideration to the wishes of fit parents}} regarding visitation rights.
cards.easyContent: Child custody includes legal custody (decision-making) and physical custody (where the child lives), which can be sole or joint. Courts decide custody and visitation based on the child’s best interests, and will deny or limit visitation only if it would endanger the child, though non-parents may sometimes obtain visitation if a strong relationship and best interests are shown and parents’ wishes are respected.
cards.mediumContent: Custody is divided into legal custody (authority over major life decisions) and physical custody (who has possession and control of the child); both can be joint or sole. Courts apply a best-interests-of-the-child standard, considering parents’ and, to a lesser extent for younger children, the child’s wishes, each parent’s ability and willingness to meet the child’s needs, the child’s relationships with parents, siblings, and others, and the child’s adjustment to home, school, and community. When one parent has sole physical custody, the other is usually entitled to reasonable visitation unless visitation would endanger the child’s wellbeing. Non-parents may receive visitation where they have a substantial relationship with the child, visitation is in the child’s best interests, and courts give special weight to the wishes of fit parents.
cards.hardContent: There are two primary types of custody: legal custody, which is the right to make major decisions affecting the child’s life (education, healthcare, religion, etc.), and physical custody, which involves possession and day-to-day control of the child. Either type can be joint or sole; in joint arrangements, parents may share decision-making while the child primarily resides with one parent, or the child may divide time between both homes. Custody and visitation determinations are governed by the best-interests-of-the-child standard. Factors commonly include: (1) each parent’s wishes; (2) the child’s wishes, with greater weight for older children and little weight for young children (e.g., under eight); (3) each parent’s ability and willingness to provide for the child’s physical, emotional, and developmental needs; (4) the child’s interaction and interrelationship with parents, siblings, and other significant people; and (5) the child’s adjustment to home, school, and community. When one parent has sole physical custody, the noncustodial parent is generally entitled to reasonable visitation. However, visitation may be denied or significantly restricted if the court finds that visitation would endanger the child’s wellbeing. Non-parents, such as grandparents or other caregivers, may obtain visitation if they have a substantial relationship with the child and visitation is in the child’s best interests, but the court must give special consideration and deference to the wishes of fit parents regarding third-party visitation.
cards.mnemonic: Best interests: W-W-CARE—Wishes, Wishes, Care, Adjustment, Relationships, Endangerment.
cards.clozeLite: Custody includes {{c1::legal custody}} (major decisions) and {{c2::physical custody}} (possession); courts use the {{c3::best-interests-of-the-child}} test and may {{c4::deny visitation if it endangers the child}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Modification of Child Support and Custody Agreements
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 015. Modification of Child Support and Custody Agreements
cards.front: Modification of Child Support and Custody Agreements
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Once a court enters a decree regarding spousal support, child support, or child custody, the decree generally is only modifiable upon a showing of a significant change in circumstances. 1.1. Significant change in circumstances required: Standards differ slightly for each type of order, but if modification arises on the exam, look for and note any significant change in circumstances. 2. Spousal support: 2.1. Changing a support award requires a substantial, material, and unanticipated change in either party's circumstances. 2.2. Self-induced changes generally will not justify modifying a support order (e.g., a party cannot voluntarily take a lower-paying job and get reduced support obligations). 3. Child support: 3.1. Child support orders are modifiable based on a substantial change in circumstances that affects either: 3.1.1. The needs of the children, or 3.1.2. The ability of the parent to pay. 3.2. Self-induced changes: Same rules as for spousal support. 4. Child custody: 4.1. Modification of a child custody order requires the parent to show a substantial, material change in circumstances. 4.2. Courts will not change a custody order unless the change is in the child's best interests.
cards.frontPrompt: When can a court modify existing spousal support, child support, or child custody orders, and what standards apply to each?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: Once a court enters a decree regarding {{c1::spousal support}}, {{c2::child support}}, or {{c3::child custody}}, the decree generally is only modifiable upon a showing of a {{c4::significant change in circumstances}}. 1.1. Significant change in circumstances required: Standards differ slightly for each type of order, but if modification arises on the exam, look for and note any {{c4::significant change in circumstances}}. 2. Spousal support: 2.1. Changing a support award requires a {{c5::substantial, material, and unanticipated change}} in either party's circumstances. 2.2. {{c6::Self-induced changes}} generally will not justify modifying a support order (e.g., a party cannot voluntarily take a lower-paying job and get reduced support obligations). 3. Child support: 3.1. Child support orders are modifiable based on a {{c7::substantial change in circumstances}} that affects either: 3.1.1. The {{c8::needs of the children}}, or 3.1.2. The {{c9::ability of the parent to pay}}. 3.2. {{c6::Self-induced changes}}: Same rules as for spousal support. 4. Child custody: 4.1. Modification of a child custody order requires the parent to show a {{c5::substantial, material change in circumstances}}. 4.2. Courts will not change a custody order unless the change is in the child's {{c10::best interests}}.
cards.easyContent: Support and custody orders are generally modifiable only upon a substantial change in circumstances, and custody changes must also serve the child’s best interests.
cards.mediumContent: A court may modify spousal support, child support, or child custody only upon a substantial change in circumstances. Spousal and child support require a substantial, material, and typically unanticipated change in needs or ability to pay, and self-induced changes usually do not justify modification. Custody may be modified only if there is a substantial change in circumstances and the modification is in the child’s best interests.
cards.hardContent: Once a court enters a decree regarding spousal support, child support, or child custody, it may generally be modified only upon a significant change in circumstances. For spousal support, the moving party must show a substantial, material, and unanticipated change in either party’s circumstances; self-induced changes, such as voluntarily taking a lower-paying job, usually do not justify modification. Child support orders are modifiable upon a substantial change in circumstances affecting either the children’s needs or the parent’s ability to pay, and self-induced changes are treated like in spousal support. Child custody orders require a substantial, material change in circumstances, and courts will not change custody unless the modification is in the child’s best interests.
cards.mnemonic: CHANGE + BEST: Change Needed; Best Interests for custody.
cards.clozeLite: Courts may modify {{c1::spousal support}}, {{c2::child support}}, or {{c3::child custody}} only upon a {{c4::substantial change in circumstances}}, and custody changes must also be {{c5::in the child’s best interests}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 016. Rights of Unmarried Co Habitants
cards.front: Rights of Unmarried Co Habitants – Overview
cards.backPlain: Unmarried cohabitants generally do not receive any special marital status merely from living together, unless they satisfy the requirements for a common law marriage. However, they can: 1. Enforce valid express contracts between them to share property or economic benefits, so long as sexual services are not the sole consideration. 2. Obtain relief based on implied-in-fact contracts, or have their relationship characterized as a joint venture, partnership, or subject to equitable remedies like constructive trusts. 3. On breakup, seek equitable and restitutionary remedies—such as resulting trusts, constructive trusts, or quantum meruit—to allocate property or compensate for contributions and prevent unjust enrichment.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the overall legal framework governing the rights and remedies of unmarried cohabitants regarding property and economic arrangements during and after cohabitation?
cards.cloze: Unmarried cohabitants generally do not receive any {{c1::special marital status}} merely from living together, unless they satisfy the requirements for a {{c2::common law marriage}}. They can, however, {{c3::enforce valid express contracts}}, rely on {{c4::implied-in-fact contracts or joint venture/partnership theories}}, and seek {{c5::equitable or restitutionary remedies}} such as resulting trusts, constructive trusts, or quantum meruit upon breakup.
cards.easyContent: Living together does not make unmarried cohabitants spouses, but they can enforce valid agreements and seek equitable or restitutionary remedies—like trust theories and quantum meruit—when they separate.
cards.mediumContent: Unmarried cohabitants gain no special marital status merely by living together unless they meet common law marriage requirements. Their rights are mainly contractual and equitable: they may enforce valid express contracts (not based solely on sexual services), rely on implied-in-fact contract or joint venture/partnership theories, and on breakup pursue equitable/restitutionary remedies such as resulting trusts, constructive trusts, and quantum meruit to prevent unjust enrichment.
cards.hardContent: Unmarried cohabitants are not treated as spouses solely because they live together, unless they satisfy the jurisdiction’s requirements for a common law marriage. Instead, their rights in property and economic arrangements come from contract and equity. They can enforce valid express contracts to share property or economic benefits so long as sexual services are not the sole consideration. Courts may also infer implied-in-fact contracts based on the parties’ conduct or characterize the relationship as a joint venture or partnership. When cohabitants separate, courts may invoke equitable and restitutionary remedies—such as resulting trusts, constructive trusts, and quantum meruit—to allocate property interests or compensate for services and contributions and thereby prevent unjust enrichment.
cards.mnemonic: No Status, Just C-E: Contracts and Equity (R-C-Q trusts, quantum meruit).
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) status and express contracts; (2) implied contracts and joint venture/partnership/constructive trust theories; (3) breakup remedies of resulting trust, constructive trust, and quantum meruit.
cards.clozeLite: Unmarried cohabitants get {{c1::no marital status}} from living together; rights are {{c2::contractual}} and {{c3::equitable}} ({{c4::express/implied contracts}} and {{c5::trusts, quantum meruit}}).

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Non Marital Children and Paternity Actions
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 017. Non Marital Children and Paternity Actions
cards.front: Non Marital Children and Paternity Actions
cards.backPlain: A non-marital child is one born to an unmarried woman. 1. Discrimination: 1.1. Distinctions based on non-marital child status are almost always unconstitutional. 1.2. Note: If you see any exam question where a child is denied benefits or rights (e.g., child support, government benefits, inheritance) due to their non-marital child status, it is likely invalid. 2. Establishing paternity: 2.1. A paternity suit may be brought to establish a non-marital child's biological parent. 2.2. Such suits are often brought by the child or mother for the purpose of obtaining support from the child's father. 2.3. Once paternity is established, a duty of support attaches. 2.4. Additionally, the father may seek visitation and custody rights. 3. Admissible evidence in paternity actions may include: 3.1. Blood or genetic tests, which parties may be required to take. 3.2.
