Prior statements regarding paternity by deceased family members. 3.3. Medical testimony about a father's sterility and/or probability of paternity based on time elapsed between birth and sex. 3.4. Admissions or acknowledgments by the alleged parent.
cards.frontPrompt: How are non-marital children protected from discrimination, how is paternity established, and what types of evidence are admissible in paternity actions?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::non-marital child}} is one born to an {{c2::unmarried woman}}. 1. Discrimination: 1.1. Distinctions based on {{c3::non-marital child status}} are almost always {{c4::unconstitutional}}. 1.2. If a child is denied benefits or rights (e.g., child support, government benefits, inheritance) due to non-marital status, it is likely {{c4::invalid}}. 2. Establishing {{c5::paternity}}: 2.1. A paternity suit may be brought to establish a non-marital child's {{c6::biological parent}}. 2.2. Such suits are often brought by the {{c7::child or mother}} to obtain {{c8::support}} from the child's father. 2.3. Once paternity is established, a {{c9::duty of support}} attaches. 2.4. Additionally, the father may seek {{c10::visitation}} and {{c11::custody}} rights. 3. Admissible evidence in paternity actions may include: 3.1. {{c12::Blood or genetic tests}}, which parties may be required to take. 3.2. {{c13::Prior statements regarding paternity}} by deceased family members. 3.3. {{c14::Medical testimony}} about a father's {{c15::sterility}} and/or probability of paternity based on {{c16::timing between intercourse and birth}}. 3.4. {{c17::Admissions or acknowledgments}} by the alleged parent.
cards.easyContent: Non-marital children generally cannot be denied benefits based on their status, and paternity actions can establish a biological father’s duty of support, visitation, and custody using evidence like genetic tests and admissions.
cards.mediumContent: A non-marital child is born to an unmarried woman, and governmental or legal distinctions based on non-marital status are almost always unconstitutional, so denials of child support, benefits, or inheritance on that basis are usually invalid. Paternity actions, typically brought by the mother or child, establish the biological parent; once paternity is proven, a duty of support arises and the father may seek visitation and custody. Admissible evidence in paternity suits includes genetic tests, prior family statements, medical testimony about sterility or conception timing, and the alleged parent’s admissions.
cards.hardContent: A non-marital child is one born to an unmarried woman. Distinctions based on non-marital child status are almost always unconstitutional, and attempts to deny benefits or rights such as child support, government benefits, or inheritance solely because of non-marital status are likely invalid. Paternity may be established through a paternity suit, often brought by the child or mother to obtain support from the father; once paternity is established, a duty of support attaches, and the father may also seek visitation and custody rights. In paternity actions, courts may consider blood or genetic tests (which parties can be compelled to take), prior statements regarding paternity by deceased relatives, medical testimony regarding sterility and the probability of paternity based on timing of intercourse and birth, and admissions or acknowledgments by the alleged parent.
cards.mnemonic: N-P-E: Non-marital protected, Paternity gives support, Evidence = tests, testimony, admissions.
cards.clozeLite: Distinctions based on {{c1::non-marital child status}} are almost always {{c2::unconstitutional}}. {{c3::Paternity actions}} use {{c4::genetic tests}} and {{c5::admissions}} to establish support duties.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 018. Adoption
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: An adoption terminates the legal relationship between biological parents and their child (if not already terminated) and establishes a new legal relationship between the adoptive parent and child. 2. Process: 2.1. Consent of both biological parents is generally required. 2.2. An unwed father's consent may not be necessary if he has not assumed parental responsibility. 2.3. But an unwed father considered fit to be a parent has a constitutional right to have an opportunity to develop a quality relationship with his infant child. 2.4. Consent of the adoptee may be required for prospective adoptees over a certain age (usually 12 or older, depending on state law). 3. Withdrawal of biological parent consent: 3.1. Withdrawal is not allowed after the adoption is finalized. 3.2. Before an adoption decree is entered, withdrawal may be allowed if the court determines it is in the adoptee's best interests. 4. Payment prohibited: 4.1. Most states prohibit adopting parents from paying money to biological parents beyond pregnancy-related medical expenses (i.e., it is illegal to buy and sell children).
cards.frontPrompt: What legal effects does adoption have on parent-child relationships, and what are the key rules about consent, withdrawal of consent, and payment to biological parents?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: An {{c1::adoption}} terminates the {{c2::legal relationship between biological parents and their child}} (if not already terminated) and establishes a new {{c3::legal parent-child relationship}} between the {{c4::adoptive parent}} and child. 2. Process: 2.1. {{c5::Consent of both biological parents}} is generally required. 2.2. An {{c6::unwed father's}} consent may not be necessary if he has not {{c7::assumed parental responsibility}}. 2.3. But an unwed father considered {{c8::fit to be a parent}} has a {{c9::constitutional right}} to have an {{c10::opportunity to develop a quality relationship}} with his infant child. 2.4. Consent of the {{c11::adoptee}} may be required for prospective adoptees over a certain age (usually {{c12::12 or older}}, depending on state law). 3. Withdrawal of biological parent consent: 3.1. Withdrawal is {{c13::not allowed after}} the adoption is finalized. 3.2. Before an adoption decree is entered, withdrawal may be allowed if the court determines it is in the adoptee's {{c14::best interests}}. 4. Payment prohibited: 4.1. Most states prohibit adopting parents from paying money to biological parents beyond {{c15::pregnancy-related medical expenses}} (i.e., it is illegal to {{c16::buy and sell children}}).
cards.easyContent: Adoption cuts off the legal relationship with the biological parents and creates a new one with the adoptive parents, generally requires parental and sometimes child consent, limits withdrawal of consent, and forbids paying more than pregnancy-related expenses.
cards.mediumContent: Adoption terminates the legal relationship between the child and biological parents and creates a new legal parent-child relationship with the adoptive parent. Typically, both biological parents must consent, though an unwed father who has not assumed parental responsibility may not need to consent, while a fit unwed father has a constitutional right to an opportunity to build a relationship with his infant. Older adoptees (often 12 or older) may also need to consent. Biological parents generally cannot withdraw consent after the adoption is finalized; before the decree, withdrawal may be permitted if it is in the adoptee’s best interests. Most states bar adoptive parents from paying biological parents anything beyond pregnancy-related medical expenses.
cards.hardContent: An adoption terminates the legal relationship between the biological parents and the child, if not already terminated, and establishes a new legal parent-child relationship between the adoptive parent and child. The process generally requires the consent of both biological parents. An unwed father’s consent may not be needed if he has not assumed parental responsibility, but an unwed father who is fit to parent has a constitutional right to an opportunity to develop a meaningful relationship with his infant child. Many states require the consent of the adoptee once the child reaches a specified age, commonly around 12. Biological parents cannot withdraw consent after the adoption is finalized; prior to entry of the adoption decree, withdrawal may be allowed if the court finds that it is in the adoptee’s best interests. Most states prohibit adoptive parents from paying biological parents beyond pregnancy-related medical expenses, reflecting the rule that children may not be bought or sold.
cards.mnemonic: Adoption CUTS & CREATES: cut bio ties, create new, consent, no baby-selling.
cards.clozeLite: Adoption {{c1::terminates biological parents' rights}} and {{c2::creates a new legal parent-child relationship}}; requires {{c3::parental (and sometimes child) consent}} and {{c4::no payments beyond pregnancy-related expenses}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 019. Adoption Alternatives (Donors and Surrogacy)
cards.backPlain: 1. Donors: 1.1. One who produces sperm or an egg used for reproduction generally does not have parental rights in a conceived child. 1.2. The mother's husband is generally presumed to be the father of a child born from artificial insemination. 1.3. Most states extinguish parental rights of sperm or egg donors. 1.4. Exception: Donors may have parental rights if agreed to in writing by the donor and intended parents. 2. Surrogacy: 2.1. Surrogacy occurs where a woman agrees to bear a child conceived through assisted reproduction (using the intended parents' eggs or sperm or both) for the intended parents. 2.2. Agreement: The surrogate, the surrogate's husband (if she is married), and the intended parents enter into a written agreement in which the surrogate relinquishes her rights and duties as a parent. 2.3. Most states allow surrogacy in some form and treat the agreement as a contract.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the default parental rights rules for sperm or egg donors and for parties to surrogacy arrangements?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Donors}}: 1.1. One who produces {{c2::sperm or an egg}} used for reproduction generally does {{c3::not have parental rights}} in a conceived child. 1.2. The {{c4::mother's husband}} is generally presumed to be the {{c5::father}} of a child born from {{c6::artificial insemination}}. 1.3. Most states {{c7::extinguish parental rights}} of sperm or egg donors. 1.4. Exception: Donors may have parental rights if {{c8::agreed to in writing}} by the donor and intended parents. 2. {{c9::Surrogacy}}: 2.1. Surrogacy occurs where a woman agrees to bear a child conceived through {{c10::assisted reproduction}} (using the intended parents' eggs or sperm or both) for the {{c11::intended parents}}. 2.2. Agreement: The {{c12::surrogate}}, the surrogate's {{c13::husband}} (if she is married), and the {{c11::intended parents}} enter into a {{c14::written agreement}} in which the surrogate {{c15::relinquishes her rights and duties as a parent}}. 2.3. Most states allow surrogacy in some form and treat the agreement as a {{c16::contract}}.
cards.easyContent: Sperm and egg donors are usually not legal parents, with limited written-agreement exceptions, and surrogacy agreements typically transfer parental rights to intended parents through a written contract.
cards.mediumContent: In donor situations, a person who provides sperm or eggs for reproduction generally has no parental rights in the resulting child. Instead, the mother’s husband is usually presumed to be the legal father in artificial insemination cases, and most states extinguish donor parental rights unless a written agreement between the donor and intended parents preserves them. In surrogacy, a woman agrees to bear a child conceived through assisted reproduction using the intended parents’ genetic material; the surrogate, her spouse if any, and the intended parents sign a written agreement in which she relinquishes parental rights, and most states recognize these surrogacy agreements as enforceable contracts.
cards.hardContent: Donor and surrogacy arrangements operate as adoption alternatives. A sperm or egg donor who provides gametes for reproduction generally has no parental rights to the child conceived. In many jurisdictions, the mother’s husband is presumed to be the legal father of a child born through artificial insemination, and statutes typically extinguish the parental rights of sperm or egg donors. However, donors may retain or obtain parental rights if there is a written agreement to that effect between the donor and the intended parents. Surrogacy involves a woman agreeing to carry a child conceived via assisted reproductive technology, usually with the intended parents’ sperm, egg, or both, for those intended parents. The surrogate, her husband if she is married, and the intended parents enter into a written agreement under which the surrogate relinquishes her parental rights and duties. Most states permit some form of surrogacy and treat the surrogacy agreement as a contract.
cards.mnemonic: Donor’s not Dad; Surrogate Signs to Surrender.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::sperm or egg donor}} generally has {{c2::no parental rights}} unless {{c3::a written agreement}} preserves them; in {{c4::surrogacy}}, a {{c5::written contract}} transfers rights to intended parents.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Premarital Agreements – Definition, Consideration, and UPAA Framework
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 004-1. Premarital Agreements – Definition, Consideration, and UPAA Framework
cards.front: Premarital Agreements – Definition, Consideration, and UPAA
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition and purpose 1.1 Premarital agreements (prenups) are contracts between prospective spouses that provide for the distribution of assets and economic rights upon divorce or death in a way that varies from what the law would otherwise require. 1.2 The purpose is to alter default state law rules governing property and support, often to protect separate assets, allocate future earnings, or clarify rights at dissolution or death. 2. Consideration 2.1 Marriage is considered sufficient consideration to support a premarital agreement. 3. Uniform Premarital Agreement Act (UPAA) 3.1 Many states have adopted the Uniform Premarital Agreement Act (UPAA). 3.2 The UPAA provides rules as to what parties may include in the contract and establishes the basic framework for validity, modification, and enforcement of premarital agreements.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a premarital agreement, what purpose does it serve, what counts as consideration, and what role does the UPAA play?
cards.cloze: Premarital agreements ({{c1::prenups}}) are {{c2::contracts}} between {{c3::prospective spouses}} that alter {{c4::default state law rules}} governing {{c5::property and support}} at {{c6::divorce or death}}. The {{c7::marriage itself}} is considered sufficient {{c8::consideration}} to support the agreement. Many states follow the {{c9::Uniform Premarital Agreement Act (UPAA)}}, which sets out {{c10::what may be included}} in a premarital contract and the {{c11::framework for validity and enforcement}}.
cards.easyContent: A premarital agreement (prenup) is a contract between people who plan to marry that changes the default rules for property and support at divorce or death. The marriage itself is enough consideration, and in many states the UPAA governs what can go into the agreement and its general framework.
cards.mediumContent: A premarital agreement is a contract between prospective spouses that alters the default legal rules for property and economic rights at divorce or death. Its purpose is to let the parties control how assets and support will be handled instead of relying on state defaults. Marriage is sufficient consideration to support the agreement. Many states have adopted the UPAA, which defines the permissible scope of premarital agreements and provides a basic framework for their validity and enforcement.
cards.hardContent: Premarital agreements (prenups) are contracts entered into by prospective spouses before marriage to alter the default legal regime governing property division and support at divorce or death. They commonly address classification of property as separate or marital, allocation of future earnings, spousal support waivers or limits, and rights at death. The contemplated marriage supplies sufficient consideration; no separate exchange of value is required. In many jurisdictions, the Uniform Premarital Agreement Act (UPAA) controls, specifying what subjects may be regulated by a premarital agreement and providing a uniform framework for validity, amendment, and enforcement. The UPAA thus shapes the baseline doctrinal rules for how courts analyze prenups.
cards.mnemonic: PC-U: Prenup=Contract, Property rules changed, Consideration=marriage, UPAA governs.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card on definition, purpose, consideration, and UPAA framework.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::premarital agreement}} is a {{c2::contract between prospective spouses}} to {{c3::alter default property and support rules}}; {{c4::marriage is sufficient consideration}} under the {{c5::UPAA framework}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Premarital Agreements – Formal and Substantive Validity Requirements
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 004-2. Premarital Agreements – Formal and Substantive Validity Requirements
cards.front: Premarital Agreements – Validity: Writing, Voluntariness, Disclosure
cards.backPlain: 1. Basic requirements for validity 1.1 Writing (Statute of Frauds) (a) A premarital agreement must be in writing to satisfy the Statute of Frauds. 1.2 Voluntariness (a) The agreement must be entered into voluntarily. (b) It must be free from fraud, duress, or overreaching (e.g., no coercion, threats, or extreme time pressure). 1.3 Full and fair disclosure / knowledge (a) Each party must fully and fairly disclose his or her financial worth (assets, liabilities, and income). (b) Alternatively, a party may waive the right to disclosure after having adequate knowledge of the other’s financial situation. 1.4 Effect of noncompliance (a) Failure to meet writing, voluntariness, or disclosure standards can render the agreement unenforceable in whole or in part under the UPAA and similar state law.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the core formal and substantive validity requirements for a premarital agreement under the UPAA and similar laws?
cards.cloze: To be valid, a premarital agreement must satisfy three main requirements: 1. {{c1::Writing}} – The agreement must be in writing to satisfy the {{c2::Statute of Frauds}}. 2. {{c3::Voluntariness}} – The agreement must be entered into {{c4::voluntarily}}, free from {{c5::fraud, duress, or overreaching}}. 3. {{c6::Full and fair disclosure}} – Each party must {{c7::fully and fairly disclose}} his or her {{c8::financial situation}} (or {{c9::knowingly waive}} the right to disclosure after {{c10::adequate knowledge}}). If these requirements are not met, the premarital agreement may be {{c11::unenforceable}} in whole or in part under the {{c12::UPAA}} or similar state law.
cards.easyContent: For a prenup to be valid, it must be in writing, entered into voluntarily (without fraud, duress, or overreaching), and based on full and fair financial disclosure (or a knowing waiver after adequate knowledge). Failure on any of these can make the agreement unenforceable.
cards.mediumContent: Under the UPAA and comparable statutes, a valid premarital agreement must: (1) be in writing to satisfy the Statute of Frauds; (2) be entered into voluntarily, meaning no fraud, duress, or overreaching; and (3) be supported by full and fair disclosure of each party’s assets, liabilities, and income, or a knowing waiver after adequate knowledge. Failure to satisfy writing, voluntariness, or disclosure requirements can cause the court to refuse enforcement of all or part of the agreement.
cards.hardContent: The UPAA and analogous state laws impose both formal and substantive prerequisites for the validity of premarital agreements. Formally, the agreement must be memorialized in a writing signed by the parties to satisfy the Statute of Frauds. Substantively, the agreement must be the product of true voluntariness: it cannot be procured through fraud (e.g., misrepresenting assets), duress (e.g., threats of cancelling the wedding at the last minute), or overreaching (e.g., extreme pressure or lack of meaningful choice). Additionally, each party must have full and fair disclosure of the other’s financial circumstances—assets, liabilities, and income—or must knowingly and voluntarily waive the right to detailed disclosure after having adequate knowledge of the other’s finances. Where the writing, voluntariness, or disclosure requirements are not met, courts under the UPAA may decline to enforce the agreement, either in whole or as to particularly problematic provisions.
cards.mnemonic: Validity = "W-V-D": Writing, Voluntariness, full Disclosure.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card focused on validity requirements: writing, voluntariness, and full and fair disclosure/waiver.
cards.clozeLite: A valid prenup under the UPAA requires {{c1::a writing}}, {{c2::voluntariness (no fraud, duress, or overreaching)}}, and {{c3::full and fair financial disclosure or a knowing waiver}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Premarital Agreements – Amendment, Revocation, and Enforcement Scrutiny
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 004-3. Premarital Agreements – Amendment, Revocation, and Enforcement Scrutiny
cards.front: Premarital Agreements – Amendment, Revocation, and Enforcement
cards.backPlain: 1. Amendment and revocation 1.1 Method (a) A premarital agreement may be revoked or amended only by a written agreement signed by both parties. 1.2 Consideration (a) An amendment to a premarital agreement is enforceable without separate consideration. 2. Enforcement and judicial scrutiny 2.1 Strict scrutiny of premarital agreements (a) Courts strictly scrutinize premarital contracts under the UPAA and similar state law. 2.2 Focus of scrutiny (a) Scrutiny focuses on: (i) Voluntariness of execution (including absence of fraud, duress, or overreaching). (ii) Full and fair financial disclosure (or valid waiver) at the time of execution. (iii) Whether the terms were unconscionable at the time of execution (and in some jurisdictions, also at the time of enforcement). 2.3 Role of legal counsel (a) Whether each party was represented by independent legal counsel may be a factor in determining voluntariness and fairness. (b) Some states require representation by counsel (or a meaningful opportunity to obtain counsel) for validity.
cards.frontPrompt: How can a premarital agreement be amended or revoked, and how do courts scrutinize its enforcement under the UPAA and similar laws?
cards.cloze: A premarital agreement may be {{c1::revoked or amended}} only by a {{c2::written agreement}} {{c3::signed by both parties}}, and an {{c4::amendment}} is enforceable {{c5::without separate consideration}}. Courts {{c6::strictly scrutinize}} enforcement of premarital agreements under the {{c7::UPAA}} and similar laws, focusing on: - {{c8::Voluntariness}} (no fraud, duress, or overreaching), - {{c9::Full and fair financial disclosure}} or a valid waiver, and - Whether the terms were {{c10::unconscionable}} at {{c11::execution}} (and sometimes at {{c12::enforcement}}). Whether each party had {{c13::independent legal counsel}} may be an important factor, and some states {{c14::require}} counsel or a meaningful chance to obtain it.
cards.easyContent: A prenup can only be changed or revoked by another written, signed agreement, and no new consideration is needed. Courts strictly scrutinize enforcement, looking at voluntariness, financial disclosure, and unconscionability (usually at execution, sometimes also at enforcement), and they often consider whether each party had a lawyer.
cards.mediumContent: Under the UPAA, premarital agreements may be revoked or amended only through a subsequent written agreement signed by both parties; amendments do not require new consideration. When enforcing a prenup, courts strictly scrutinize it, examining whether it was entered into voluntarily, whether there was full and fair financial disclosure or a valid waiver, and whether its terms were unconscionable at execution (and sometimes at enforcement). Independent legal counsel for each party is a significant factor in this analysis, and some states make counsel or an opportunity to obtain counsel a formal requirement.
cards.hardContent: The UPAA permits revocation or amendment of a premarital agreement only by a later written agreement signed by both parties. No additional consideration is required for an amendment; the underlying marriage and original exchange suffice. At the enforcement stage, courts apply strict scrutiny to premarital agreements. They assess whether the agreement was voluntarily executed (free of fraud, duress, or overreaching), whether there was full and fair disclosure or a knowing waiver after adequate knowledge, and whether the terms were unconscionable at the time of execution. Some jurisdictions also examine unconscionability at the time of enforcement, especially where circumstances have changed dramatically. The presence of independent legal counsel for each party is highly probative of fairness and voluntariness; many courts treat lack of counsel as a red flag, and some states require either representation or a meaningful opportunity to obtain counsel for the agreement to be enforceable.
cards.mnemonic: Change by W2; enforce with V-D-U: Voluntary, Disclosure, Unconscionable.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card covering amendment/revocation and judicial enforcement scrutiny (voluntariness, disclosure, unconscionability, counsel).
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::UPAA}}, a prenup can be {{c2::amended or revoked only by a later written, signed agreement}}, {{c3::no new consideration is required}}, and courts scrutinize {{c4::voluntariness}}, {{c5::financial disclosure or waiver}}, and {{c6::unconscionability}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 004-4. Premarital Agreements – Child-Related Provisions
cards.front: Premarital Agreements – Limits on Child-Related Provisions
cards.backPlain: 1. Child-related provisions in premarital agreements 1.1 Child custody (a) Provisions in a premarital agreement purporting to fix child custody are not binding on the court. (b) Courts decide custody based on the best interests of the child at the time of separation or divorce. 1.2 Child support (a) Provisions attempting to limit or waive child support obligations are not binding on the court. (b) In some states, such provisions may be void as against public policy. 1.3 Rationale (a) Child custody and child support are considered rights of the child, not merely the parents, and cannot be bargained away in advance. (b) Courts retain ultimate authority to determine custody and support in light of the child’s best interests.
cards.frontPrompt: How do courts treat child custody and child support provisions in premarital agreements, and why?
cards.cloze: Provisions in a premarital agreement that attempt to predetermine {{c1::child custody}} or {{c2::child support}} are {{c3::not binding}} on the court and may be {{c4::void}} in some states. Courts decide custody and support at the time of {{c5::dissolution}} based on the {{c6::best interests of the child}}. The rationale is that custody and support are considered {{c7::rights of the child}}, not purely contractual rights of the parents, and thus {{c8::cannot be bargained away in advance}}.
cards.easyContent: Child custody and child support terms in a prenup do not bind the court and may be void. Courts always decide these issues later based on the child’s best interests, because custody and support are rights of the child, not just the parents’ contract rights.
cards.mediumContent: Premarital agreements cannot lock in binding rules for child custody or child support. Clauses attempting to do so are not binding on the court and, in some states, are void as against public policy. At the time of separation or divorce, the court independently determines custody and support under a best interests of the child standard, reflecting the view that these issues involve the child’s rights and cannot be contracted away by the parents.
cards.hardContent: Although premarital agreements can effectively allocate property and spousal support rights, they cannot conclusively fix arrangements for child custody or child support. Provisions that attempt to dictate custody or restrict or waive child support obligations are not binding and may be deemed void under state public policy. At dissolution, the court must determine custody and support according to the best interests of the child, taking into account statutory factors such as the child’s needs, the parents’ capacities, and stability. The law treats custody and support as rights held by the child, not merely as interests that the parents may bargain away by contract. Accordingly, while a court may consider the parents’ expressed preferences as one data point, it retains ultimate authority to set custody and support irrespective of any contrary terms in the premarital agreement.
cards.mnemonic: Kids rule the prenup: courts use best interests, not parents’ deal.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card focused on the nonbinding nature of child custody and support provisions in premarital agreements and the best interests standard.
cards.clozeLite: Prenups {{c1::cannot bind}} courts on {{c2::child custody}} or {{c3::child support}}; courts decide later by {{c4::best interests of the child}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 006-1. Annulment – Definition and Legal Effect
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of annulment: • Annulment is a judicial declaration that an alleged marriage was invalid from its inception because an impediment existed at the time of marriage. • As a result, the marriage is treated as if it never legally occurred. 2. Void vs. voidable marriages: • A marriage may be subject to annulment if it is either void or voidable. • Whether a particular ground makes a marriage void or voidable varies by state. • Void marriages are considered invalid without the need for a decree, but an annulment action is often brought to clarify status. • Voidable marriages are valid unless and until annulled by a court.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an annulment, and how does it differ in effect from divorce with respect to void and voidable marriages?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition of annulment: • {{c1::Annulment}} is a judicial declaration that an alleged marriage was {{c2::invalid from its inception}} because an {{c3::impediment existed at the time of marriage}}. • As a result, the marriage is treated as if it {{c4::never legally occurred}}. 2. Void vs. voidable marriages: • A marriage may be annulled if it is either {{c5::void}} or {{c6::voidable}}. • Whether a particular ground makes a marriage void or voidable {{c7::varies by state}}. • {{c8::Void}} marriages are considered invalid even without a decree, but an annulment action is often brought to {{c9::clarify the parties’ status}}. • {{c10::Voidable}} marriages are treated as valid {{c11::unless and until a court annuls them}}.
cards.easyContent: Annulment is a court ruling that a supposed marriage was invalid from the start because of a problem present when the parties married. The marriage is treated as if it never existed. Annulment can apply to both void and voidable marriages, depending on state law.
cards.mediumContent: Annulment is a judicial declaration that an alleged marriage was invalid from its inception because an impediment existed at the time of marriage. Unlike divorce, which ends a valid marriage, annulment treats the marriage as though it never legally existed. Annulment can be used for both void and voidable marriages, though whether a given ground makes the marriage void or voidable differs by state. Void marriages are inherently invalid, while voidable marriages remain valid unless and until annulled.
cards.hardContent: Annulment is a judicial proceeding that results in a declaration that a purported marriage was invalid from the moment of its formation because an impediment existed at the time of marriage. Consequently, the marital status is retroactively denied, and the parties are treated as though they were never validly married. A marriage may be challenged by annulment whether it is void—invalid ab initio without the need for a decree—or voidable—valid for all purposes unless and until a court annuls it. The line between void and voidable grounds, however, is jurisdiction-specific, so which defects support each classification varies by state.
cards.mnemonic: ANX: Annulment = Actually Never eXisted in law.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::annulment}} is a {{c2::judicial declaration}} that a marriage was {{c3::invalid from inception}}, unlike {{c4::divorce}}, which {{c5::ends a valid marriage}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 006-2. Annulment – Grounds (Void and Voidable)
cards.front: Annulment – Grounds for Void or Voidable Marriage
cards.backPlain: 1. General note on grounds: • Grounds for annulment are typically considered voidable unless otherwise specified. • Classification as void or voidable varies by state, but some grounds are commonly treated as void. 2. Grounds that typically render a marriage void: • Bigamy or polygamy: A marriage entered into when one party is already married is generally void. • Consanguinity: Marriage between close blood relatives (such as parent-child or siblings) is generally void. 3. Other common grounds for annulment (usually voidable): • Non-age: One spouse was under the statutory age at the time of marriage (subject to possible ratification or confirmation rules by statute). • Incurable physical impotence: Inability to have normal sexual relations that existed at the time of marriage. • Incapacity to consent to marriage: – Mental incompetence: The party did not understand the nature of the marriage contract. – Intoxication or incapacitation due to drugs or alcohol at the time of marriage. – Fraud going to an essential aspect of the marriage. – Duress or coercion that overbore the party’s free will to marry.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main recognized grounds for annulment, and which ones commonly render a marriage void versus voidable?
cards.cloze: 1. General note on grounds: • Grounds for annulment are typically considered {{c1::voidable}} unless otherwise specified, and their classification {{c2::varies by state}}. 2. Grounds that typically render a marriage {{c3::void}}: • {{c4::Bigamy or polygamy}}: Marriage when one party is already married. • {{c5::Consanguinity}}: Marriage between {{c6::close blood relatives}}. 3. Other common grounds for annulment (usually {{c7::voidable}}): • {{c8::Non-age}}: One spouse was under the {{c9::statutory age}} at the time of marriage. • {{c10::Incurable physical impotence}}: Inability to have {{c11::normal sexual relations}} existing at the time of marriage. • {{c12::Incapacity to consent}} to marriage, including: – {{c13::Mental incompetence}} (did not understand the nature of marriage). – {{c14::Intoxication or incapacitation due to drugs or alcohol}} at the time of marriage. – {{c15::Fraud}} going to an essential aspect of the marriage. – {{c16::Duress or coercion}} that overbore the party’s free will to marry.
cards.easyContent: Main grounds for annulment include: bigamy or polygamy and close-blood marriage (consanguinity), which usually make the marriage void; and non-age, incurable impotence, and incapacity to consent (because of mental incompetence, intoxication, fraud, or duress), which are usually treated as voidable.
cards.mediumContent: Annulment grounds are often treated as voidable unless a statute or rule makes them void. Commonly void grounds include bigamy or polygamy and consanguinity (close-blood relatives). Other frequent grounds are non-age, incurable physical impotence, and incapacity to consent due to mental incompetence, intoxication from drugs or alcohol, fraud going to an essential aspect of the marriage, or duress. These typically render the marriage voidable, subject to jurisdictional variation and possible ratification rules.
cards.hardContent: Courts annul marriages when a qualifying impediment existed at the time of marriage. As a default, these grounds are considered voidable unless a statute or settled rule treats them as void, and this classification can vary by jurisdiction. The clearest void grounds are bigamy or polygamy—where a party was already lawfully married—and consanguinity, meaning marriage between close blood relatives such as lineal kin or siblings. Other common grounds—usually voidable—include non-age, where a spouse is under the statutory minimum age; incurable physical impotence, defined as an inability to engage in normal sexual relations existing when the marriage was formed; and incapacity to consent, which may arise from mental incompetence, intoxication or drug impairment at the time of marriage, or wrongful inducement such as fraud that goes to an essential aspect of the marital relationship or duress that overbears the party’s free will to marry.
cards.mnemonic: Void: "Big Close" (Bigamy, Close kin). Others: NII (Non-age, Impotence, Incapacity).
cards.clozeLite: Annulment grounds usually {{c1::voidable}} unless law makes them {{c2::void}}. {{c3::Bigamy/polygamy}} and {{c4::consanguinity}} are typically void; {{c5::non-age}}, {{c6::incapacity to consent}} usually voidable.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Annulment – Spousal Support and Property Division
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 006-3. Annulment – Spousal Support and Property Division
cards.backPlain: 1. Spousal support in annulment: • Many states allow temporary spousal support (alimony pendente lite) while an annulment suit is pending. • Fewer states allow ongoing or post-annulment spousal support once the marriage has been declared invalid. • Where permitted, post-annulment support often depends on statutory provisions and may consider factors similar to those in divorce (e.g., need and ability to pay). 2. Property division on annulment: • Most courts attempt to divide property to place the parties, as nearly as possible, in the positions they occupied before the marriage commenced. • Courts may treat property acquired during the putative marriage as if it were held in a form of partnership or joint ownership, guided by equity. • Some jurisdictions have specific statutory schemes for property rights following annulment, particularly where there was a good-faith belief in the validity of the marriage.
cards.frontPrompt: How do courts typically handle spousal support and division of property when granting an annulment?
cards.cloze: 1. Spousal support in annulment: • Many states allow {{c1::temporary spousal support}} (alimony pendente lite) while an annulment suit is pending. • {{c2::Fewer states}} allow {{c3::ongoing or post-annulment spousal support}} once the marriage has been declared invalid. • Where permitted, post-annulment support usually depends on {{c4::statutory provisions}} and factors similar to those in {{c5::divorce}} (such as need and ability to pay). 2. Property division on annulment: • Most courts attempt to divide property so as to place the parties, as nearly as possible, in the {{c6::positions they occupied before the marriage commenced}}. • Courts often treat property acquired during the putative marriage under {{c7::equitable principles}}, sometimes analogizing to {{c8::partnership or joint ownership}}. • Some jurisdictions have specific {{c9::statutory schemes}} for property rights after annulment, especially where there was a {{c10::good-faith belief in the validity}} of the marriage.
cards.easyContent: In annulment cases, many states allow temporary support while the case is pending, but far fewer allow ongoing support after the marriage is declared invalid. For property, courts usually divide assets to put the parties as close as possible to their pre-marriage positions, often using equitable principles and, in some states, specific statutes.
cards.mediumContent: When a court grants an annulment, it may award temporary spousal support during the suit, but relatively few jurisdictions permit ongoing support afterward. Where allowed, post-annulment support typically depends on statute and familiar need/ability factors. For property, courts generally use equitable principles to divide assets in a way that approximates each party’s pre-marriage position, sometimes treating property acquired during the putative marriage like partnership or joint property. Some states add statutory rules, especially for good-faith putative spouses.
cards.hardContent: In the annulment context, many states authorize temporary spousal support while the action is pending to prevent unfair hardship, but significantly fewer authorize continuing support once the marriage is declared void or voidable and set aside. Where post-annulment support is permitted, courts usually look to enabling statutes and apply factors much like those in divorce, including the parties’ needs, earning capacities, and the equities of the situation. For property, the dominant approach is restorative: courts seek to allocate property so that the parties are, as nearly as practicable, returned to the positions they held before the purported marriage. To do this, courts invoke equitable principles and may treat property acquired during the putative marriage as akin to partnership or jointly owned property. Some jurisdictions overlay this with statutory schemes, especially protecting parties who entered the marriage in good faith but later learn it was invalid.
cards.mnemonic: Annulment: Temp, Rare, Restore – temporary support, rare ongoing, restore property.
cards.clozeLite: On {{c1::annulment}}, courts often allow {{c2::temporary support}} but {{c3::ongoing support is rare}}; property is divided to {{c4::restore pre-marriage positions}} using {{c5::equitable principles}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Divorce – Fault vs. No-Fault and Grounds
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 007-1. Divorce – Fault vs. No-Fault and Grounds
cards.front: Divorce – Fault vs. No-Fault and Grounds
cards.frontPrompt: How does modern no-fault divorce differ from traditional fault-based divorce, and what are the common no-fault grounds recognized by states?
cards.backPlain: 1. Effect of a divorce decree 1.1 A divorce decree terminates the marriage relationship. 2. Fault vs. no-fault divorce 2.1 Historically, divorce required proof of fault; divorce was permitted only if one party was at fault. 2.2 Some states still retain fault-based grounds (e.g., adultery, cruelty, desertion), but every state now offers some form of no-fault divorce. 2.3 Unless otherwise noted, bar exam questions typically concern no-fault divorce. 3. Common grounds for no-fault divorce (vary by state; one or more may be required) 3.1 Irretrievably broken / irreconcilable differences 3.1.1 This is the most common no-fault ground. 3.1.2 In some states, it is the only ground for divorce. 3.1.3 In such states, other factors (e.g., separation period) are merely evidence that the marriage is irretrievably broken. 3.2 Living separate and apart 3.2.1 The parties have been living separate and apart for a prescribed time. 3.2.2 The period is usually six months to one year, but the exact time depends on the state. 3.3 Incompatibility 3.3.1 The parties are incompatible and cannot continue the marital relationship. 4. Key exam points 4.1 Know that all states provide some form of no-fault divorce. 4.2 Be able to identify typical no-fault grounds: irretrievable breakdown, separation for a period, and incompatibility.
cards.cloze: A {{c1::divorce decree}} {{c2::terminates the marriage relationship}}. Historically, divorce was {{c3::fault-based}}, requiring proof that one spouse was {{c4::at fault}}. Some states still recognize {{c5::fault grounds}}, but every state now offers {{c6::no-fault divorce}}. Common no-fault grounds include: - {{c7::Irretrievably broken}} marriage (a.k.a. {{c8::irreconcilable differences}}), often the {{c9::primary or exclusive}} ground in some states. - {{c10::Living separate and apart}} for a prescribed period, usually {{c11::six months to one year}}. - {{c12::Incompatibility}} between the spouses.
cards.easyContent: A divorce decree ends the marriage. Historically, divorce required showing a spouse was at fault, but now all states allow no-fault divorce, usually based on irretrievable breakdown, living apart for a set period, or incompatibility.
cards.mediumContent: A divorce decree terminates the marital relationship. Traditionally, divorce required proof of fault, such as adultery or cruelty, but although some states still recognize fault grounds, all states now offer no-fault divorce. Typical no-fault grounds include an irretrievably broken marriage (irreconcilable differences), living separate and apart for a prescribed period (often six months to a year), and incompatibility.
cards.hardContent: A divorce decree formally terminates the marriage relationship. Historically, divorce was available only on fault-based grounds, requiring proof that one spouse engaged in marital misconduct (e.g., adultery, cruelty, desertion). While some jurisdictions continue to recognize such fault grounds, every state now provides a no-fault option. Common no-fault grounds are: (1) an irretrievably broken marriage, often expressed as irreconcilable differences and sometimes serving as the state’s sole ground; (2) living separate and apart for a statutorily prescribed period, commonly six months to one year; and (3) incompatibility between the spouses. On the bar, unless otherwise indicated, assume questions about grounds for divorce refer to this modern no-fault framework.
cards.mnemonic: No-fault grounds = "I-S-I": Irretrievably broken, Separation, Incompatibility.
cards.clozeLite: All states offer {{c1::no-fault divorce}} based on {{c2::irretrievably broken marriage}}, {{c3::living separate and apart}}, or {{c4::incompatibility}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 007-2. Divorce – Defenses
cards.frontPrompt: What traditional defenses to divorce are recognized in some states, and how do they affect the court’s ability to grant a divorce in modern practice?
cards.backPlain: 1. Availability of defenses 1.1 Some states recognize traditional defenses to divorce. 1.2 Common defenses include: 1.2.1 Collusion: The parties agreed to fabricate grounds for divorce or suppress valid defenses. 1.2.2 Condonation: The complaining spouse forgave the marital misconduct (e.g., resumed cohabitation after adultery) with full knowledge of it. 1.2.3 Recrimination: The complaining spouse is also guilty of marital misconduct ("unclean hands"). 2. Modern effect of defenses 2.1 Even where available, these defenses are less significant in the no-fault era. 2.2 Courts generally will not force a marriage to continue if one party wants a dissolution. 2.3 Thus, defenses are more likely to affect timing or terms rather than the ultimate ability to dissolve the marriage. 3. Exam focus 3.1 Recognize and define common defenses (collusion, condonation, recrimination). 3.2 Know that they rarely bar a no-fault divorce entirely, because courts avoid compelling an unwilling marriage.
cards.cloze: Some states recognize traditional {{c1::defenses to divorce}} such as: - {{c2::Collusion}}: spouses agree to fabricate grounds or suppress valid defenses. - {{c3::Condonation}}: the innocent spouse {{c4::forgives}} known misconduct, often by {{c5::resuming cohabitation}}. - {{c6::Recrimination}}: the complaining spouse is also guilty of {{c7::marital misconduct}} ("unclean hands"). In modern practice, however, these defenses are {{c8::less significant}} because courts generally will not {{c9::force a marriage to continue}} if one party seeks dissolution.
cards.easyContent: Some states still recognize defenses like collusion, condonation, and recrimination, but today courts usually will not use defenses to force spouses to stay married if one wants a divorce.
cards.mediumContent: Traditional defenses to divorce include collusion (faked grounds), condonation (forgiveness of known misconduct, often shown by resuming cohabitation), and recrimination (both parties are guilty of misconduct). These may still be pled in some states, but in the no-fault era courts generally will not deny a divorce solely on these grounds, because they will not compel an unwilling marriage.
cards.hardContent: Although the rise of no-fault divorce has reduced their practical impact, some jurisdictions continue to recognize defenses such as: (1) collusion, where the spouses conspire to manufacture grounds or to conceal valid defenses; (2) condonation, where the aggrieved spouse, with full knowledge of the misconduct, forgives it—often evidenced by resuming marital relations; and (3) recrimination, which bars relief when the petitioner is also guilty of marital misconduct (the "unclean hands" doctrine). Modern courts, however, are reluctant to use these defenses to deny dissolution altogether and generally will not force the continuance of a marriage when one spouse seeks a no-fault divorce, though defenses may affect the timing or terms of the decree.
cards.mnemonic: Defenses C-C-R: Collusion, Condonation, Recrimination.
cards.clozeLite: Traditional defenses to divorce include {{c1::collusion}}, {{c2::condonation}}, and {{c3::recrimination}}, but {{c4::modern no-fault courts rarely deny divorce on these grounds}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 007-3. Legal Separation vs. Divorce
cards.frontPrompt: What is legal separation, how does it differ from divorce, what issues can the court decide in a separation proceeding, and when can legal separation convert to an absolute divorce?
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition and basic effect of legal separation 1.1 A legal separation is a judicially recognized parting of the spouses that does not terminate the marriage. 1.2 It is not a divorce and does not end the marital status. 1.3 Because the marriage continues, the parties cannot remarry. 2. Issues determined in a legal separation proceeding 2.1 Courts can adjudicate many of the same issues addressed in a divorce: 2.1.1 Property rights and division between the spouses. 2.1.2 Spousal support (alimony or maintenance). 2.1.3 Child custody arrangements. 2.1.4 Child support obligations. 3. Conversion to absolute divorce 3.1 In some states, a legal separation can become an absolute divorce. 3.2 Conversion is typically available at the request of one or both parties after a specified period of separation. 3.3 Once converted, the marriage is terminated and the parties may remarry. 4. Contrast with divorce 4.1 Divorce immediately terminates the marriage and allows remarriage. 4.2 Legal separation maintains the marital bond but clarifies rights and obligations while the spouses live apart.
cards.cloze: A {{c1::legal separation}} is a {{c2::judicially recognized parting}} of the spouses that {{c3::does not terminate the marriage}}. It is {{c4::not a divorce}}: - The parties {{c5::remain married}}. - They {{c6::cannot remarry}}. In a separation proceeding, the court can decide: - {{c7::Property}} rights and division, - {{c8::Spousal support}}, - {{c9::Child custody}}, and - {{c10::Child support}}. In some states, a legal separation can later be {{c11::converted into an absolute divorce}} at the request of the parties after a {{c12::specified period of time}}.
cards.easyContent: Legal separation is a court-ordered separation that does not end the marriage, so the spouses cannot remarry. The court can still decide property, support, and custody issues, and in some states the separation can later be converted into an absolute divorce.
cards.mediumContent: Legal separation is a judicially recognized separation of spouses that leaves the marriage intact, so the parties remain married and cannot remarry. In the separation proceeding, courts can resolve property division, spousal support, child custody, and child support. In some jurisdictions, after a specified period of separation, the parties may request that the legal separation be converted into an absolute divorce, which then terminates the marriage.
cards.hardContent: Legal separation is a judicial decree recognizing that spouses will live apart while formally preserving the marital relationship. Unlike divorce, legal separation does not terminate marital status, and the spouses therefore cannot remarry. Nonetheless, the court may adjudicate many of the same issues addressed in divorce—such as division of property, spousal support, child custody, and child support—providing structure and enforceable obligations during separation. In some states, after a statutorily prescribed period and upon the request of one or both parties, a decree of legal separation may be converted into an absolute divorce, at which point the marriage is dissolved and the parties are free to remarry.
cards.mnemonic: Separation: Still Spouses, Stuff and Support Settled.
cards.clozeLite: In {{c1::legal separation}}, spouses {{c2::remain married and cannot remarry}}, but courts can decide {{c3::property and support}} and {{c4::child custody and support}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 008-1. Jurisdiction for Annulment
cards.backPlain: Jurisdiction over annulment actions is in state courts. 1. Domicile-based jurisdiction: A state in which either spouse is domiciled has subject-matter jurisdiction to enter an annulment decree. 2. Place-of-marriage jurisdiction: In most states, courts in the state where the marriage was entered into and recognized also have jurisdiction to adjudicate an annulment. 3. Key idea: Annulment jurisdiction focuses on the parties’ domicile and, in many jurisdictions, the state of celebration of the marriage.
cards.frontPrompt: Which states have jurisdiction to grant an annulment, and what roles do domicile and the place of celebration of the marriage play?
cards.cloze: Jurisdiction over {{c1::annulment}} actions is in {{c2::state courts}}. 1. {{c3::Domicile-based jurisdiction}}: A state in which {{c4::either spouse is domiciled}} has subject-matter jurisdiction to enter an annulment decree. 2. {{c5::Place-of-marriage jurisdiction}}: In {{c6::most states}}, courts in the state where the {{c7::marriage was entered into and recognized}} also have jurisdiction to adjudicate an annulment. 3. Key idea: Annulment jurisdiction focuses on the parties’ {{c8::domicile}} and, in many jurisdictions, the {{c9::state of celebration of the marriage}}.
cards.easyContent: A state can grant an annulment if either spouse is domiciled there, and in most states also if it is the state where the marriage was entered and recognized.
cards.mediumContent: State courts hear annulment actions. Subject-matter jurisdiction is proper in any state where either spouse is domiciled, and in most states also in the state where the marriage was entered into and recognized. Thus, annulment can often be brought in the domicile state or the state of celebration.
cards.hardContent: Annulment jurisdiction lies in state courts and is typically broad. Any state in which either spouse is domiciled has subject-matter jurisdiction to enter an annulment decree, reflecting the state’s interest in the status of its domiciliaries. Additionally, in most jurisdictions, courts in the state where the marriage was entered into and recognized also have jurisdiction to adjudicate annulment, even if neither spouse is currently domiciled there.
cards.mnemonic: Annulment A-D-C: Annulment – Domicile or Celebration.
cards.clozeLite: Annulment jurisdiction exists in any state where {{c1::either spouse is domiciled}} and, in most states, also {{c2::where the marriage was entered into and recognized}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Divorce Jurisdiction, Durational Residency, and Full Faith and Credit
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 008-2. Divorce Jurisdiction, Durational Residency, and Full Faith and Credit
cards.front: Divorce Jurisdiction, Durational Residency, and Full Faith and Credit
cards.backPlain: 1. Domicile requirement for divorce: - To establish subject-matter jurisdiction over a divorce action, at least one spouse must be domiciled in the forum state where the action is brought. 2. Durational residency requirements: - Many states require a minimum period of residency (durational residency) before a spouse can file for divorce. - Purpose: To ensure a genuine connection to the forum and to prevent forum shopping for favorable divorce laws. 3. Full Faith and Credit for divorce decrees: - Under the U.S. Constitution’s Full Faith and Credit Clause, a divorce decree granted by one state must be recognized by other states if the rendering state had proper jurisdiction. - Jurisdiction for Full Faith and Credit purposes is satisfied when one or both spouses was domiciled in the state that issued the decree. - Other states may, in limited circumstances, collaterally attack the decree by disputing the existence of domicile in the rendering state.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the domicile and durational residency requirements for divorce jurisdiction, and when must other states give Full Faith and Credit to a divorce decree?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Domicile requirement for divorce}}: - To establish subject-matter jurisdiction over a divorce action, at least {{c2::one spouse must be domiciled}} in the forum state where the action is brought. 2. {{c3::Durational residency}} requirements: - Many states require a {{c4::minimum period of residency}} before a spouse can file for divorce. - Purpose: To ensure a {{c5::genuine connection}} to the forum and to prevent {{c6::forum shopping}}. 3. {{c7::Full Faith and Credit}} for divorce decrees: - Under the U.S. Constitution’s Full Faith and Credit Clause, a divorce decree granted by one state must be {{c8::recognized by other states}} if the rendering state had proper jurisdiction. - Jurisdiction for Full Faith and Credit purposes is satisfied when {{c9::one or both spouses was domiciled}} in the state that issued the decree. - Other states may, in limited circumstances, {{c10::collaterally attack}} the decree by disputing the existence of {{c11::domicile}} in the rendering state.
cards.easyContent: A court can grant a divorce if at least one spouse is domiciled in the forum, often after meeting a durational residency requirement. Other states must recognize the divorce under the Full Faith and Credit Clause if the granting state had a true domicile-based jurisdiction.
cards.mediumContent: Divorce jurisdiction is based on domicile: at least one spouse must be domiciled in the forum. Many states also require a minimum durational residency period to show a real connection and prevent forum shopping. Under the Full Faith and Credit Clause, a divorce decree validly granted by a state where one or both spouses was domiciled must be recognized by sister states, although they may collaterally attack the decree by challenging the alleged domicile in the rendering state.
cards.hardContent: To exercise subject-matter jurisdiction over a divorce, a state generally requires that at least one spouse be domiciled within its borders. Often, the legislature also mandates a specific durational residency period as a prerequisite to filing, ensuring a meaningful relationship to the forum and limiting opportunistic forum shopping for favorable dissolution laws. Once a divorce decree is entered by a court that had proper domicile-based jurisdiction, the Full Faith and Credit Clause obligates other states to recognize the decree as valid. However, sister states retain a narrow ability to collaterally attack the decree by disputing whether the spouse who purportedly established domicile in the rendering state in fact satisfied the legal requirements for domicile.
cards.mnemonic: "D-D-F" for divorce: Domicile, Durational residency, and Full Faith and Credit.
cards.clozeLite: Divorce {{c1::jurisdiction}} is based on {{c2::domicile}} of at least one spouse, often after {{c3::durational residency}}; valid domicile-based decrees get {{c4::Full Faith and Credit}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Limits on Jurisdiction over Property and Support in Marriage Actions
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 008-3. Limits on Jurisdiction over Property and Support in Marriage Actions
cards.front: Limits on Jurisdiction over Property and Support in Marriage Actions
cards.backPlain: 1. Status vs. economic incidents: - A court can determine the marital status (e.g., divorced or still married) based on domicile alone. - However, adjudicating property rights and support obligations involves economic incidents that require personal jurisdiction. 2. Property outside the state: - A court generally does not have jurisdiction to determine rights to property located outside the state (especially real property) unless it has personal jurisdiction over the parties whose interests are affected. 3. Support orders (spousal or child support): - A court cannot enter binding support decrees (e.g., alimony, child support) against a party unless it has personal jurisdiction over that party. - In practice, to fully resolve property division and support, courts typically need personal jurisdiction over both spouses, not just status jurisdiction based on one spouse’s domicile.
cards.frontPrompt: How does jurisdiction to determine marital status differ from jurisdiction to decide property division and support, especially for out-of-state property and support orders?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Status vs. economic incidents}}: - A court can determine {{c2::marital status}} (e.g., divorced or still married) based on {{c3::domicile alone}}. - However, adjudicating {{c4::property rights}} and {{c5::support obligations}} involves economic incidents that require {{c6::personal jurisdiction}}. 2. {{c7::Property outside the state}}: - A court generally does not have jurisdiction to determine rights to {{c8::property located outside the state}} (especially real property) unless it has {{c9::personal jurisdiction}} over the parties whose interests are affected. 3. {{c10::Support orders}} (spousal or child support): - A court cannot enter binding {{c11::support decrees}} against a party unless it has {{c12::personal jurisdiction}} over that party. - In practice, to fully resolve {{c13::property division}} and {{c14::support}}, courts typically need {{c15::personal jurisdiction over both spouses}}, not just status jurisdiction based on one spouse’s domicile.
cards.easyContent: A court can change marital status based on one spouse’s domicile, but to divide property—especially out-of-state property—or order support, it needs personal jurisdiction over the affected parties, usually both spouses.
cards.mediumContent: Status jurisdiction based on domicile lets a state decide whether a couple is married or divorced, but that does not automatically allow the court to divide property or order support. Courts generally cannot adjudicate rights in out-of-state property or enter binding spousal or child support orders without personal jurisdiction over the parties. Thus, fully resolving property division and support typically requires personal jurisdiction over both spouses.
cards.hardContent: Family law distinguishes between status and economic incidents of marriage. A court may rely solely on domicile to adjudicate marital status, granting or denying a divorce even if it lacks personal jurisdiction over the nonresident spouse. By contrast, property division and support obligations are economic incidents that implicate due process concerns: a court typically cannot determine rights to property located outside the state—especially real property—or impose spousal or child support obligations on an absent party unless it has personal jurisdiction over that party. Consequently, while status can be changed with unilateral domicile-based jurisdiction, comprehensive resolution of economic issues in a marriage dissolution usually requires personal jurisdiction over both spouses.
cards.mnemonic: Status = domicile; Stuff & Support = PJ (personal jurisdiction).
cards.clozeLite: A court can change {{c1::marital status}} based on one spouse’s {{c2::domicile}}, but {{c3::property division}} and {{c4::support orders}} require {{c5::personal jurisdiction}} over the parties.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Unmarried Cohabitants – Status and Express Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 016-1. Unmarried Cohabitants – Status and Express Contracts
cards.front: Unmarried Cohabitants – Status and Express Contracts
cards.backPlain: 1. General legal status: 1.1. No special status: Unmarried cohabitants do not have any special legal or marital status merely by living together. 1.2. Exception – common law marriage: Cohabitants will be treated as spouses only if they satisfy the requirements for a common law marriage in that jurisdiction. 2. Express contracts between unmarried cohabitants: 2.1. Validity: Express contracts between unmarried cohabitants to share property or engage in other forms of economic sharing are generally enforceable under ordinary contract principles. 2.2. Illegality/invalidity exception: An agreement is invalid if sexual services are the sole consideration supporting the contract. 2.3. Mixed consideration: Where the agreement is supported by both lawful consideration (e.g., services, contributions, support) and sexual relations, it is usually enforceable so long as sexual services are not the sole basis.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the legal status of unmarried cohabitants, and when are their express agreements to share property or economic benefits enforceable or invalid?
cards.cloze: Unmarried cohabitants do not have any {{c1::special legal or marital status}} merely by living together. They are treated as spouses only if they satisfy the requirements for a {{c2::common law marriage}}. Express contracts between unmarried cohabitants to {{c3::share property or economic benefits}} are generally {{c4::enforceable}} under ordinary contract law, but a contract is {{c5::invalid}} if {{c6::sexual services}} are the {{c7::sole consideration}} supporting the agreement.
cards.easyContent: Living together does not make cohabitants spouses unless they meet common law marriage requirements. They can, however, make and enforce normal contracts to share property or money, except that a deal based only on sexual services is invalid.
cards.mediumContent: Unmarried cohabitants acquire no special marital status simply by cohabiting; they are only treated as spouses if they satisfy the jurisdiction’s common law marriage requirements. Nonetheless, they can enter into express contracts to share property or other economic benefits, which are generally enforceable. The main limitation is that an agreement based solely on sexual services is void as against public policy; where there is other lawful consideration, the contract can be enforced.
cards.hardContent: Cohabitation alone does not confer any spousal or marital status on unmarried partners. Absent satisfaction of statutory or common law marriage requirements, they remain legal strangers regarding marital rights. Their primary protection lies in contract: they may form valid express agreements allocating property interests, support, or economic sharing, which courts enforce under ordinary contract principles. However, if the consideration for the agreement consists solely of sexual services (e.g., an agreement to provide sexual companionship in exchange for property), the contract is invalid as against public policy. By contrast, if sexual relations are merely incidental to, or one part of, a broader arrangement supported by lawful consideration (such as domestic services, business contributions, or financial support), courts typically will enforce the contract.
cards.mnemonic: Cohabit? No spouse status; contracts OK—just not for sex-only deals.
cards.clozeLite: Unmarried cohabitants get {{c1::no marital status}} from living together, but {{c2::express contracts to share property or benefits}} are valid unless {{c3::based solely on sexual services}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Unmarried Cohabitants – Implied Contracts and Joint Venture/Partnership Theories
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 016-2. Unmarried Cohabitants – Implied Contracts and Joint Venture/Partnership Theories
cards.front: Unmarried Cohabitants – Implied Contracts & Joint Venture/Partnership
cards.backPlain: 1. Implied-in-fact contracts between unmarried cohabitants: 1.1. Definition: An implied-in-fact contract is formed by the parties’ conduct, rather than explicit words, but shows mutual assent and consideration. 1.2. Application: Courts may infer an implied-in-fact agreement between cohabitants to share property, income, or assets based on their behavior, contributions, and understandings during the relationship. 2. Alternative characterizations of the relationship: 2.1. Joint venture: The court may treat the cohabitants’ arrangement as a joint venture where they combined efforts and resources for a common economic purpose, giving rise to shared ownership or profit-sharing claims. 2.2. Partnership: Similarly, a court may construe the relationship as a partnership if the parties carried on a business or economic enterprise together for profit, making partnership rules relevant to asset division. 2.3. Constructive trust as a remedial device: In appropriate circumstances, a court may impose a constructive trust to reflect an implied or equitable obligation to hold certain property for the benefit of the other cohabitant, especially where failure to do so would unjustly enrich one party.
cards.frontPrompt: How can unmarried cohabitants obtain property or economic rights through implied-in-fact contracts or through joint venture, partnership, or similar theories?
cards.cloze: Courts may recognize {{c1::implied-in-fact contracts}} between unmarried cohabitants, formed by their {{c2::conduct}} rather than explicit words, to {{c3::share property, income, or assets}}. A court may also characterize the relationship as a {{c4::joint venture}} or {{c5::partnership}} when the parties combine efforts and resources for a {{c6::common economic or profit-seeking purpose}}. In some cases, courts may impose a {{c7::constructive trust}} as a remedial device to reflect an {{c8::equitable obligation to hold property for another}} and to prevent {{c9::unjust enrichment}}.
cards.easyContent: Even without a written deal, courts can infer an implied-in-fact contract between cohabitants from their conduct, or treat them like joint venturers or partners in a shared economic enterprise, and may impose constructive trusts to prevent unjust enrichment.
cards.mediumContent: Unmarried cohabitants can gain property or economic rights through implied-in-fact contracts, which arise from the parties’ conduct demonstrating mutual agreement to share assets or income. Courts may also view their relationship as a joint venture or partnership when they combine efforts and resources in a common economic or business enterprise, importing joint venture or partnership rules for sharing profits and assets. As a remedial overlay, courts sometimes impose constructive trusts to recognize an equitable obligation to hold certain property for the benefit of the other cohabitant and avoid unjust enrichment.
cards.hardContent: Because cohabitation itself does not create marital rights, courts look to the parties’ intent and conduct to supply contractual and equitable bases for relief. An implied-in-fact contract may be found where the cohabitants’ conduct—such as pooling funds, sharing bank accounts, or one party relying on assurances of shared ownership—manifests mutual assent and consideration to share property or economic benefits. Separately, if the parties have engaged in a common economic or business endeavor, a court may characterize the relationship as a joint venture or partnership, allowing application of those doctrines to allocate profits and assets. To further effectuate equity, courts may impose a constructive trust over property held by one cohabitant, requiring that it be held for the benefit of the other, where the circumstances show an implied or equitable obligation to share and where failure to recognize that obligation would unjustly enrich the title holder.
cards.mnemonic: Cohabitants use I-J-P: Implied, Joint venture, Partnership.
cards.clozeLite: Unmarried cohabitants may gain rights via {{c1::implied-in-fact contracts}} or by being treated as a {{c2::joint venture or partnership}}, with {{c3::constructive trusts}} to prevent {{c4::unjust enrichment}}.

cards.subject: Family Law
cards.topic: Unmarried Cohabitants – Breakup Remedies: Resulting Trust, Constructive Trust, Quantum Meruit
cards.rawHeader: Family Law 016-3. Unmarried Cohabitants – Breakup Remedies: Resulting Trust, Constructive Trust, Quantum Meruit
cards.front: Unmarried Cohabitants – Breakup Remedies (Resulting & Constructive Trusts, Quantum Meruit)
cards.backPlain: When unmarried cohabitants separate, courts may grant equitable or restitutionary remedies to allocate property and avoid unjust enrichment: 1. Equitable distribution / rehabilitative concepts: 1.1. Some courts analogize to equitable distribution or rehabilitative alimony principles when dividing property or compensating for a dependent cohabitant’s contributions, even though there is no formal marriage. 2. Resulting trust: 2.1. Definition: A resulting trust arises when one party pays purchase money for property titled in another’s name, with the intent to retain an ownership interest. 2.2. Elements: The claimant must show (a) they provided the purchase money or a specific portion of it, and (b) they intended to retain a beneficial ownership interest at the time of transfer. 3. Constructive trust: 3.1. Definition: A constructive trust is an equitable remedy imposed to prevent unjust enrichment where one party holds title to property obtained through wrongful conduct. 3.2. Purpose: It treats the title holder as a trustee for the beneficiary to strip away the unjust enrichment and restore the property to the rightful equitable owner. 4. Quantum meruit: 4.1. Definition: Quantum meruit allows recovery in quasi-contract for the fair market value of services rendered. 4.2. Purpose: It requires a party who benefited from valuable services (e.g., domestic, caregiving, or business services) to pay their fair value to avoid unjust enrichment when there is no enforceable contract or property right.
cards.frontPrompt: After unmarried cohabitants break up, what equitable and restitutionary remedies—specifically resulting trust, constructive trust, and quantum meruit—are available to allocate property or compensate for contributions?
cards.cloze: When unmarried cohabitants separate, courts may use {{c1::equitable or restitutionary remedies}} to allocate property and prevent {{c2::unjust enrichment}}. A {{c3::resulting trust}} arises when one party {{c4::pays purchase money for property}} placed in another’s name with intent to {{c5::retain a beneficial ownership interest}}. A {{c6::constructive trust}} is imposed where one party holds title obtained through {{c7::wrongful conduct}}, treating that party as a {{c8::trustee}} to strip away {{c9::unjust enrichment}}. {{c10::Quantum meruit}} is a {{c11::quasi-contract}} remedy allowing recovery of the {{c12::fair market value of services rendered}} when no enforceable contract or property right exists.
cards.easyContent: On breakup, unmarried cohabitants can get equitable and restitutionary remedies. Courts may impose a resulting trust if one paid the purchase money but title is in the other’s name, a constructive trust if property was acquired wrongfully and would unjustly enrich one party, or quantum meruit to pay for the fair value of services provided.
cards.mediumContent: Because unmarried cohabitants have no automatic marital property regime, courts often rely on equity and restitution at breakup. A resulting trust can be imposed when one cohabitant paid the purchase money for property titled in the other’s name, intending to retain an ownership interest. A constructive trust is an equitable remedy used to prevent unjust enrichment when one party holds title acquired through wrongful or inequitable conduct, effectively making that party a trustee for the other. Quantum meruit is a quasi-contract theory that allows the contributing cohabitant to recover the fair market value of services rendered—such as domestic or business services—to avoid unjust enrichment when no valid contract or formal property interest exists.
cards.hardContent: On separation, unmarried cohabitants cannot rely on statutory marital property regimes, so courts often invoke equitable and restitutionary doctrines. Some courts loosely analogize to equitable distribution or rehabilitative alimony concepts to structure relief for a dependent cohabitant. More specifically: (1) A resulting trust may be recognized where one cohabitant provided the purchase money for property, but title was placed in the other’s name, provided the payer intended to retain a beneficial ownership interest at the time of acquisition. The resulting trust gives the payer an equitable share proportionate to their contribution. (2) A constructive trust is an equitable device imposed when one party holds title obtained by fraud, breach of confidence, or other wrongful conduct; it forces the title holder to hold the property for the benefit of the other and prevents unjust enrichment. (3) Quantum meruit is a quasi-contract remedy allowing the contributing cohabitant to recover the fair market value of services rendered (such as household, caregiving, or business services) when there is no enforceable contract or property right, thereby compensating contributions and avoiding unjust enrichment.
cards.mnemonic: Breakup "R-C-Q": Resulting (paid), Constructive (cheated), Quantum (worked).
cards.clozeLite: Unmarried cohabitants may get {{c1::resulting trusts}} for {{c2::purchase-money contributions}}, {{c3::constructive trusts}} for {{c4::wrongful acquisition of title}}, and {{c5::quantum meruit}} for {{c6::services rendered}}.
